Adjacent to the cathedral stands the chapel consecrated to Our Lady of the Forsaken (Virgen de los desamparados or Mare de Déu dels Desamparats).

Initial critiques offered a range of perspectives. Ken Tucker of Entertainment Weekly, for instance, felt that "As TV, American Idol is crazily entertaining; as music, it's dust-mote inconsequential." Others, however, contended that "the most striking aspect of the series was the genuine talent it revealed." The program was also labeled a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation." Other facets of the show also drew criticism. The extensive product placement, in particular, was highlighted, and some reviewers were severe in their condemnation of what they perceived as its blatant commercial strategies. Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune, for example, charged that American Idol is "a conniving multimedia monster" that has "absorbed the sin of our debauched culture and spit them out in a lump of reconstituted evil." Furthermore, the decision to have the season one winner perform the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was met with widespread disapproval. Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post sarcastically observed that "The terrorists have won" and, taking a swipe at the show's commercialism and voting process, questioned how the power to decide who "gets to turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala' is in the hands of the millions of girls who have made American Idol a hit. Them and a handful of phone-redialer geeks who have been clocking up to 10,000 calls each week for their contestant of choice (but who, according to Fox, are in absolutely no

The 1980s saw significant media attention on the royal family's private affairs and viewpoints, resulting in numerous sensational press stories, some of which lacked complete accuracy. Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, famously instructed his staff: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much of a fuss about it afterwards." On September 21, 1986, newspaper editor Donald Trelford noted in The Observer that "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost sight of ... it is not just that some papers don't check their facts or accept denials: they don't care if the stories are true or not." Reports, particularly in The Sunday Times on July 20, 1986, indicated that the Queen was concerned by Margaret Thatcher's economic strategies, which were seen as creating social divisions. She was reportedly troubled by high unemployment, multiple riots, the severe miners' strike, and Thatcher's reluctance to impose sanctions on South Africa's apartheid government. Royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal were among the sources for these rumors, though Shea asserted his comments were misconstrued and exaggerated by speculation. Thatcher herself was rumored to have stated that the Queen would cast her vote for the Social Democratic Party, who were Thatcher's political rivals. According to Thatcher's biographer John Campbell, "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making." Despite earlier reports of animosity, Thatcher subsequently expressed her personal respect for the Queen. After John Major succeeded Thatcher as prime minister, the Queen personally bestowed two honours upon her: membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described Elizabeth as a "behind the scenes force" in the effort to end apartheid.

The palace spans 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), reaches a height of 24 metres (79 ft), and encompasses over 77,000 square metres (830,000 sq ft) of internal area. Its total floor space is more modest than that of the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, or the Forbidden City. It contains 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The main reception rooms are situated on the piano nobile, located behind the palace's west-facing garden façade. At the heart of this elaborate suite of state rooms is the Music Room, distinguished by its prominent bow, which forms a key architectural element of the façade. The Blue and White Drawing Rooms are positioned on either side of the Music Room. Centrally located within the suite, and functioning as a connecting corridor for the state rooms, is the Picture Gallery, which is illuminated from above and stretches 55 yards (50 m) in length. The Gallery showcases numerous artworks by masters such as Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens, and Vermeer; other rooms accessible from the Picture Gallery include the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room. The Green Drawing Room serves as a substantial anteroom to the Throne Room, forming part of the ceremonial procession route from the Guard Room at the summit of the Grand Staircase. The Guard Room features white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert depicted in Roman attire, displayed within a tapestry-lined tribune. These highly formal spaces are reserved solely

To expand and solidify the dynasty's influence in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally spearheaded a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. Kangxi successfully drove Galdan's invading armies from these territories, subsequently integrating them into the empire. Galdan ultimately perished during the Dzungar–Qing War. By 1683, Qing forces secured Taiwan's surrender from Zheng Keshuang, Koxinga's grandson, whose grandfather had seized the island from Dutch colonists to use as a base against the Qing. Zheng Keshuang was granted the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and, upon relocating to Beijing, was integrated into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners. From 1661 to 1662, several Ming princes, such as Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, had joined Koxinga in Taiwan, residing within the Kingdom of Tungning. In 1683, the Qing repatriated the 17 Ming princes remaining on Taiwan to mainland China, where they lived out their lives in exile, having been spared execution. The conquest of Taiwan liberated Kangxi's troops for a series of engagements concerning Albazin, the easternmost outpost of the Tsardom of Russia. Zheng's former soldiers in Taiwan, including the renowned rattan shield troops, were also incorporated into the Eight Banners and deployed by the Qing against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The Treaty of Nerchinsk in 1689 marked China's inaugural formal agreement with a European power, maintaining border peace for nearly two centuries. Following Galdan's demise, his Tibetan Buddhist adherents sought to influence the selection of the subsequent Dalai Lama. Kangxi then dispatched two armies to Lhasa, Tibet's capital, to install a Dalai Lama favorable to the Qing.

From the 1970s, Stuart Hall's groundbreaking work, alongside that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and Angela McRobbie, sparked an international intellectual movement. As the discipline developed, it began to combine political economy, communication, sociology, social theory, literary theory, media theory, film/video studies, cultural anthropology, philosophy, museum studies, and art history to examine cultural phenomena or texts. In this field, researchers frequently concentrate on how particular phenomena relate to issues of ideology, nationality, ethnicity, social class, and/or gender. Cultural studies is concerned with the meaning and practices of everyday life. These practices comprise the ways people engage in specific activities (such as watching television or dining out) within a given culture. This field investigates the meanings and uses individuals attribute to various objects and practices. Specifically, culture involves those meanings and practices maintained independently of reason. Watching television to gain a public perspective on a historical event should not be considered culture, unless referring to the medium of television itself, which may have been culturally selected; however, schoolchildren watching television after school with their friends to "fit in" certainly qualifies, as there is no rational basis for one's participation in this practice. Recently, as capitalism has spread worldwide (a process termed globalization), cultural studies has begun to analyze local and global forms of resistance to Western hegemony. Globalization in this context can be defined as Western civilization, which undermines the cultural integrity of other cultures and is therefore viewed as repressive, exploitative, and harmful to many people in different places.

Libya's economy increasingly embraced privatization; despite rejecting the nationalized industry policies of socialism championed in The Green Book, government officials maintained they were cultivating "people's socialism" over capitalism. Gaddafi supported these changes, advocating for extensive privatization in a March 2003 address. The oil industry was largely divested to private companies in 2003, and by 2004, Libya had attracted $40 billion in direct foreign investment, a sixfold increase from 2003. Portions of the Libyan populace protested these reforms through public demonstrations, and in March 2006, hard-line revolutionaries gained control of the GPC cabinet; though they reduced the speed of the changes, they did not discontinue them. In 2010, plans were announced to privatize half of the Libyan economy over the subsequent decade. While political liberalization did not accompany these shifts, with Gaddafi retaining ultimate authority, the government did grant more powers to municipal councils in March 2010. A growing number of reformist technocrats entered the country's administration; most notable was Gaddafi's son and presumed successor, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, who openly criticized Libya's human rights record. He led a group that proposed a new constitution, though it was never adopted, and in October 2009 he was appointed to lead the PSLC. Saif also promoted tourism and established several private media outlets in 2008, but these were nationalized in 2009 after they criticized the government. In October 2010, Gaddafi issued an apology to African leaders on behalf of Arab nations for their involvement in the African slave trade.

Mammalian fur, or pelage, exhibits color variation among different populations, within a single population, and even across an individual animal. A range of light to dark coloration is frequently observed within mammalian species. While age can sometimes dictate this color change, other factors are responsible in different instances. Varied mammalian coloration often arises from selective pressures, including ecological interactions with other species or specific environmental conditions. These pressures favor particular hues to enhance survival. Camouflage is considered a primary selective force influencing mammalian coloration, though sexual selection, communication, and physiological mechanisms are also known to affect its evolutionary development. As the most prevalent mechanism for color variation, camouflage helps animals hide from both predators and prey. Additionally, coat color serves for intraspecies communication, such as alerting conspecifics to predators, signaling health for reproduction, facilitating mother-to-offspring interactions, and deterring threats. Research indicates that in certain situations, distinct coat colors between males and females can convey information about nutrition and hormone levels, crucial for mate choice. A final mechanism for pelage color variation involves physiological responses, like thermoregulation in tropical or arctic climates. Despite extensive observations regarding color variation, the precise genetic links between coat color and specific genes largely remain undiscovered. Genetic loci containing pigmentation genes are understood to influence phenotype by: 1) modifying the spatial arrangement of hair pigmentation, and 2) adjusting the hair's density and distribution. Quantitative trait mapping is currently employed to clarify the distribution of loci governing pigmentation variability. Nevertheless, despite identifying these genetic sites, the mechanisms of their gene expression are still largely unexplored.

During the mid-18th century, specifically the French Enlightenment, the term "humanism" began to be used in a more ideological sense. An anonymous contributor to a French Enlightenment periodical in 1765 wrote about "The general love of humanity...a virtue hitherto quite nameless among us," suggesting they "venture to call 'humanism'," because "the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary thing." The late 18th and early 19th centuries witnessed the establishment of numerous grassroots "philanthropic" and benevolent societies focused on human betterment and the spread of knowledge, some religiously affiliated and some not. After the French Revolution, the idea that human virtue could be cultivated solely through human reason, separate from traditional religious bodies—a concept opponents of the Revolution ascribed to Enlightenment philosophes like Rousseau—was vehemently attacked by prominent religious and political conservatives, including Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, who condemned it as a deification or idolatry of humanity. This led "humanism" to acquire a negative meaning. The Oxford English Dictionary records an English clergyman's use of "humanism" in 1812 to refer to those who believed in Christ's "mere humanity" (as opposed to his divine nature), such as Unitarians and Deists. In this charged environment, where established ecclesiastical groups often became defensive and automatically opposed political and social reforms like extending suffrage and universal schooling, liberal reformers and radicals embraced Humanism as an alternative "religion of humanity." The anarchist Proudhon, known for stating "property is theft," utilized "humanism" to describe a "culte, déification de l’humanité" ("worship, deification of humanity"). Ernest Renan, in L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848 (1848–49), declared: "It is my deep conviction that pure humanism will be the religion of the future, that is, the cult of all that pertains to humanity—all of life, sanctified and raised to the level of a moral value."

More frequently, in political landscapes involving three or more parties, it's improbable for any single party to secure power independently, leading parties to collaborate and establish coalition governments. This pattern has been increasingly observed in the politics of the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s, and is a near-constant reality in Germany at the federal and state levels, as well as in most local constituencies. Furthermore, since its inception, the Republic of Iceland has never had a government not formed by a coalition (typically comprising the Independence Party and one other, often the Social Democratic Alliance). A comparable situation exists in the Republic of Ireland; since 1989, no single party has governed autonomously. During this period, numerous coalition governments have been established, always spearheaded by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Political progress is often facilitated by a coalition government more readily than in systems dominated by one or two parties. [dubious – discuss] If factions within a two-party system hold deep disagreements on policy objectives or core principles, they may be slow to enact policy changes, a scenario currently evident in the U.S. with power divided between Democrats and Republicans. Yet, coalition governments themselves often struggle, sometimes for extended periods, to implement policy changes and frequently fail entirely, with post-World War II France and Italy serving as prime illustrations. Conversely, when a single party in a two-party system controls all elected branches, policy reforms can be both rapid and substantial. Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson benefited from such favorable circumstances, as did Republicans like Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan, though separated by time. Barack Obama briefly held this advantage between 2009 and 2011.

Emotions serve as drivers for social interactions and relationships, consequently linking directly to fundamental physiological processes, particularly stress systems. This connection is vital because emotions relate to the anti-stress complex, which includes an oxytocin-attachment system pivotal for bonding. Emotional temperaments, or phenotypes, impact social integration and reproductive success within complex social frameworks (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These attributes are shared across diverse species and taxa, originating from genetic influences and their continuous inheritance. The information encoded in DNA sequences provides the instructional guide for assembling the proteins that constitute our cells. Zygotes receive genetic data from their parental germ cells, and at each speciation event, heritable traits that enabled an ancestor's survival and successful reproduction are passed on, alongside new traits potentially beneficial to the offspring. Over the five million years since the lineages leading to modern humans and chimpanzees diverged, only about 1.2% of their genetic material has changed. This implies that all characteristics distinguishing us from chimpanzees, including our behaviors, must be encoded within this minimal genetic difference. Researchers studying animal behaviors have primarily identified intraspecific examples of gene-dependent behavioral phenotypes. In voles (Microtus spp.), minor genetic variations in a vasopressin receptor gene correspond to significant species-level differences in social organization and mating systems (Hammock & Young 2005). Another potential example illustrating behavioral differences is the FOXP2 gene, which is involved in the neural circuitry governing speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). Its present form in humans differs from that of chimpanzees by only a few mutations and has been present for approximately 200,000 years, coinciding with the appearance of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization collectively form the foundational elements of emotions.

The implications are extensive, given that numerous research fields currently employ identity as a primary framework for analyzing various phenomena. One significant consequence of both identity and its formation is evident within professional environments. This challenge intensifies considerably in professions that are stigmatized or categorized as "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). According to Tracy and Trethewey (2005), individuals are drawn to or repelled by specific occupations partly based on how well those roles affirm their "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Tretheway 2005, p. 169). Certain jobs are associated with varying degrees of stigma or prestige. Tracy illustrates this point with the example of correctional officers striving to overcome the perception of being "glorified maids" (Tracy & Tretheway 2005). This involves "the process by which people arrive at justifications of and values for various occupational choices," encompassing factors like job satisfaction and general quality of life (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33). Individuals in such roles must devise strategies to forge an identity that is acceptable to them. "Crafting a positive sense of self at work is more challenging when one's work is considered 'dirty' by societal standards" (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 7). This means that managing the stigma associated with a job isn't solely about enabling employees to feel content in their position. "If employees must navigate discourses that question the viability of their work, and/ or experience obstacles in managing taint through transforming dirty work into a badge of honor, it is likely they will find blaming the client to be an efficacious route in affirming their identity"

In their 2003 paper, "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles extensively criticize the use of FST in analyzing human populations. They contend that the 85% statistic is deceptive, as it suggests that, on average, all human populations possess 85% of total genetic diversity. This approach, they argue, fails to accurately represent human population history by treating all human groups as autonomous entities. A more accurate depiction of human group relationships acknowledges that certain groups are ancestral to others, forming paraphyletic groups relative to their descendant populations. For instance, according to the recent African origin theory, the African human population is paraphyletic to all other human groups, serving as the ancestral source from which all non-African populations originate. Furthermore, non-African groups emerged from only a small, unrepresentative subset of this African population. Consequently, all non-African groups share closer genetic ties with each other and with specific African groups (likely East Africans) than with others. Additionally, the migration out of Africa constituted a genetic bottleneck, meaning a significant portion of the genetic diversity present in Africa was not carried by the emigrant populations. This perspective illustrates human population movements not as independent events, but as a series of diversity dilutions occurring progressively further from Africa, with each founding event being a genetic subset of its parent population. Long and Kittles observed that instead of 85% of human genetic diversity being present in all human populations, roughly 100% of this diversity can be found within a single African population, while a population originating from New Guinea contains only about 70%. Despite these findings, Long and Kittles maintained that the global human population remains genetically homogeneous when compared to other mammalian species.

Darwin's book was extensively translated during his lifetime, but these translations often faced challenges in accurately conveying concepts and metaphors, and some were influenced by the translator's personal biases. Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable individuals would come forward, as translators were expected to manage their own agreements with local publishers. He welcomed the respected elderly naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn, but the German translation published in 1860 injected Bronn's own perspectives, introducing controversial themes Darwin had deliberately omitted. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races" and included essays on subjects like the origin of life, as well as a final chapter on religious implications, partly inspired by his adherence to Naturphilosophie. In 1862, Bronn produced a second edition based on the third English edition and Darwin's suggested additions, but then died of a heart attack. Darwin corresponded closely with Julius Victor Carus, who published an improved translation in 1867. Darwin's attempts to find a French translator were unsuccessful, and the 1862 translation by Clémence Royer included an introduction praising Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and promoting concepts anticipating social Darwinism and eugenics, along with numerous explanatory notes offering her own answers to doubts Darwin had expressed. Darwin corresponded with Royer concerning a second edition published in 1866 and a third in 1870, but he struggled to get her to remove her notes and was troubled by these editions. He remained unsatisfied until Edmond Barbier's translation was published in 1876. A Dutch translation by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler appeared in 1860. By 1864, further translations had emerged in Italian and Russian. During Darwin's lifetime, *Origin* also saw publication in Swedish in 1871, Danish in 1872, Polish in 1873, Hungarian in 1873–1874, Spanish in 1877, and Serbian in 1878. By 1977, it had appeared in an additional 18 languages.

Hegel assuredly aimed to retain what he deemed valid in German idealism, particularly Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does extend beyond finite inclinations. For Hegel, a fundamental identity of thought and being is necessary for the "subject" (any human observer) to comprehend any observed "object" (any external entity, possibly even another human). Under Hegel's concept of "subject-object identity," both subject and object share Spirit (Hegel's redefined, non-supernatural "God") as their conceptual (not metaphysical) inner reality—and are thus identical. However, until Spirit's "self-realization" occurs and Spirit progresses to Absolute Spirit status, the subject (a human mind) mistakenly perceives every "object" it observes as "alien," meaning separate or distinct from itself. In Hegel's words, "The object is revealed to it [to "subject"] by [as] something alien, and it does not recognize itself." Self-realization transpires when Hegel (part of Spirit's non-supernatural Mind, the collective consciousness of all humans) arrives and comprehends that every "object" is himself, because both subject and object are essentially Spirit. When self-realization happens and Spirit becomes Absolute Spirit, the "finite" (humanity) becomes the "infinite" ("God," divine), replacing the imaginary or "picture-thinking" supernatural God of theism: man becomes God. Tucker expresses it this way: "Hegelianism . . . is a religion of self-worship whose fundamental theme is given in Hegel's image of the man who aspires to be God himself, who demands 'something more, namely infinity.'" The image Hegel presents is "a picture of a self-glorifying humanity striving compulsively, and at the end successfully, to rise to divinity."

Ancient Israelite history records two periods of political autonomy: initially under the Biblical judges, and subsequently during the era of the United Monarchy. Following the dissolution of the United Monarchy, the territory was partitioned into the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. The appellation "Jew" derives from the Roman term "Judean," identifying an individual from the southern kingdom of Judah. This transition in ethnonym from "Israelites" to "Jews" (signifying an inhabitant of Judah), while absent from the Torah, is clearly presented in the Book of Esther (dating to the 4th century BCE), which forms part of the Ketuvim, the third division of the Jewish Tanakh. In 587 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar II, monarch of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, laid siege to Jerusalem, demolished the First Temple, and exiled Judah's most influential citizens. By 586 BCE, Judah lost its status as an independent kingdom, rendering its surviving Jewish population stateless. The Babylonian exile concluded in 539 BCE as the Achaemenid Empire subjugated Babylon, with Cyrus the Great granting permission for the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and reconstruct their Temple. The Second Temple was completed by 515 BCE. The province of Yehud remained a peaceful territory within the Achaemenid Empire until its collapse around 333 BCE at the hands of Alexander the Great. Political independence for Jews was re-established during the Hasmonean dynasty, from 140 to 37 BCE, and continued to some extent under the Herodian dynasty, from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Following the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, the majority of Jews have resided in the diaspora. As an ethnic minority in virtually every nation where they reside (with the exception of modern Israel), they have often faced

At the Tokyo Game Show in September 2012, Sony announced a new, more compact PS3 redesign (CECH-4000) slated for release in late 2012, offering either a 250 GB or 500 GB hard drive. Three versions of the Super Slim model were revealed: one with a 500 GB hard drive, a second with a 250 GB hard drive (unavailable in PAL regions), and a third with 12 GB flash storage (exclusive to PAL regions). The 12 GB model's storage was upgradable with an official standalone 250 GB hard drive. A dedicated vertical stand was also released for this model. In the United Kingdom, the 500 GB model launched on September 28, 2012, while the 12 GB model followed on October 12, 2012. In the United States, the PS3 Super Slim initially launched as part of console bundles. The 250 GB model was bundled with the Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception, releasing on September 25, 2012; the 500 GB model was bundled with Assassin's Creed III, releasing on October 30, 2012. Japan saw the black Super Slim model release on October 4, 2012, and the white Super Slim model on November 22, 2012. This Super Slim model is 20 percent smaller and 25 percent lighter than the preceding Slim model, featuring a manual sliding disc cover instead of the Slim's motorized slot-loading mechanism. The white Super Slim model was released in the United States on January 27, 2013, as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. Garnet Red and Azurite Blue colored models were introduced in Japan on February 28, 2013. The Garnet Red version arrived in North America on March 12, 2013, as a God of War: Ascension bundle with 500 GB storage, including God of War: Ascension and the God of War Saga. The Azurite Blue model was released as a GameStop exclusive with 250 GB storage.

Following the Treaty of Versailles in 1919, the city was restored to French control, aligning with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points," and this occurred without a public vote. The official transfer date was later set, retrospectively, to Armistice Day. It is questionable whether a plebiscite in Strasbourg would have resulted in a pro-French outcome, given that political factions advocating for either Alsatian autonomy or integration with France garnered only a small percentage of votes in both the most recent Reichstag and local elections. However, Alsatian autonomists who favored France had secured significant support in the region's more rural areas and other municipalities since Germany's annexation in 1871. This movement began with the inaugural Reichstag election, where the elected representatives, known as "les députés protestataires," were, until Bismarck's resignation in 1890, the sole Alsatian deputies in the German parliament to advocate for the territories' return to France. In the final Reichstag election held in Strasbourg and its surrounding areas, the Social Democrats emerged as the clear victors; the city served as the administrative hub for the region, hosted numerous Germans appointed by the central government in Berlin, and its thriving economy drew in many German residents. This demographic and economic context could account for the disparity between the rural vote and that cast in Strasbourg. Following the war, a significant number of Germans departed Strasbourg and returned to Germany; some were reported by local inhabitants, while others faced expulsion by the freshly instated authorities. The Saverne Affair remained a potent memory among Alsatians.

Zhejiang's key manufacturing sectors encompass electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical production, food processing, and building materials. In recent times, Zhejiang has implemented its distinctive "Zhejiang model" of development. This strategy prioritizes and fosters entrepreneurship, emphasizes agile small businesses responsive to market shifts, involves substantial public investments in infrastructure, and focuses on producing low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic and international markets. As a result, Zhejiang has become one of China's most affluent provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" has achieved legendary status within the country. Nevertheless, some economists now express concerns regarding the model's sustainability, arguing it is inefficient and exerts undue pressure on raw materials and public utilities. They also perceive it as a dead end, as the myriad small enterprises in Zhejiang, which mass-produce inexpensive items, are struggling to advance into more sophisticated or technologically advanced industries. The economic heart of Zhejiang is shifting from the northern region, centered around Hangzhou, southeastward to the areas around Wenzhou and Taizhou. In 2009, the per capita disposable income for urban dwellers in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603), representing an 8.3% real annual increase. For rural inhabitants, the per capita pure income was 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), showing an 8.1% real year-on-year growth. Zhejiang's nominal GDP for 2011 was recorded at 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion), with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). The primary, secondary, and tertiary industries in Zhejiang were valued at 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively in 2009.

In its nascent period, MCA also manufactured discs for other corporations, including Paramount, Disney, and Warner Bros. Some of these companies added their branding to the disc jacket to signify that MCA was not the film's owner. After Discovision Associates ceased operations in early 1982, Universal Studio's videodisc software imprint, known as MCA Videodisc until 1984, started reissuing many titles originally from DiscoVision. Unfortunately, a significant portion, like Battlestar Galactica and Jaws, were time-compressed versions of their original CAV or CLV Disco Vision editions. The time-compressed CLV re-issue of Jaws notably omitted the original soundtrack, with incidental background music replaced for the videodisc version due to licensing costs (the original music would not be accessible until the 1995 THX LaserDisc box set). A Universal/Columbia co-production released by MCA DiscoVision in both CAV and CLV versions, The Electric Horseman, is still the only home video format available with its original score preserved; even the latest DVD release features considerable music replacements for both instrumental score and Willie Nelson's songs. An MCA release of Universal's Howard the Duck displays only the opening credits in widescreen before shifting to 4:3 for the rest of the film. For numerous years, this was the sole disc-based release of the movie, until widescreen DVD formats with supplementary content became available. Additionally, the LaserDisc release of E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial is the only format to feature the deleted scene of Harrison Ford as the school headmaster admonishing Elliott for freeing the frogs in the biology class.

Agricultural societies first emerged in southeastern Europe during the 7th millennium BC, evidenced by one of Europe's earliest farming sites, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, and dating to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines have been found in the Balkans from 6000 BC, and in Central Europe by approximately 5800 BC (La Hoguette). Among the initial cultural complexes of this area is the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which later expanded throughout the Balkans, giving rise to Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča. Through a combination of cultural diffusion and migration, Neolithic traditions spread westward and northward, reaching northwestern Europe by around 4500 BC. The Vinča culture may have developed the earliest writing system, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn believes these most likely represented pictograms and ideograms rather than a truly developed form of writing. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture constructed enormous settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC. The megalithic temple complexes of Ġgantija on the Mediterranean island of Gozo (in the Maltese archipelago) and of Mnajdra (Malta) are notable for their gigantic Neolithic structures, the oldest of which date back to approximately 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni, Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated around 2500 BC; originally a sanctuary, it became a necropolis, the world's only prehistoric underground temple, showcasing a degree of artistry in stone sculpture unique to the Maltese islands in prehistory. After 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands were depopulated for several decades until a new influx of Bronze Age immigrants arrived, introducing a culture that cremated its dead and brought smaller megalithic structures called dolmens to Malta. These typically consist of small chambers covered by a large slab placed on upright stones. They are claimed to belong to a population distinct from that which built the earlier megalithic temples. It is presumed this population arrived from Sicily due to the similarity of Maltese dolmens to some small constructions found on the Mediterranean's largest island.

Popper considered knowledge objective, implying it is either genuinely true or truth-approximating, and that it possesses an inherent existence (as an object) separate from any individual who comprehends it (from *Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach*, 1972). He introduced a tripartite schema: World One, encompassing the physical realm and its states; World Two, comprising the domain of the mind, including mental states, thoughts, and sensory inputs; and World Three, representing the collective sum of human knowledge, manifested in diverse formats—essentially, the output of World Two realized through World One's components (such as books, articles, artworks, musical compositions, and all other creations of the human intellect). World Three, he contended, arises from individual human activity, much like an animal trail results from individual animals, and consequently, it possesses its own distinct existence and developmental trajectory, detached from any particular knowing individual. According to Popper, World Three's impact on the individual human intellect (World Two) is at least commensurate with World One's influence. That is to say, an individual mind's understanding is shaped as significantly by the accumulated, externalized body of human knowledge as it is by firsthand experience. Therefore, the expansion of human knowledge can be seen as contingent upon World Three's autonomous progression. However, numerous contemporary thinkers, like Daniel Dennett, have not adopted Popper's Three World hypothesis, primarily, it appears, because of its perceived likeness to mind-body dualism.

The United Kingdom did not operate with a strict separation of powers, even though its political structure frequently influenced the governmental design of the U.S. Constitution. Under the UK's Westminster system, based on parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, Parliament—composed of the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), House of Lords, and House of Commons—was the supreme lawmaking body. The executive branch, known as "His Majesty's Government," and the judiciary both acted in the King's name. Most of the King's Ministers were members of one of the two Houses of Parliament, and the Government needed to maintain majority support in the House of Commons. For example, the Lord Chancellor simultaneously served as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. Thus, the three branches of British government often deviated from the strict principle of separation of powers, despite frequent disagreements among them.

Similarly, some U.S. states in the 18th century did not strictly observe the separation of powers. In New Jersey, the Governor also functioned as a member of the state's highest court and as the presiding officer of one legislative house. Delaware's President was a member of the Court of Appeals, and the presiding officers of its two legislative houses also served as Vice Presidents in the executive department. Both Delaware and Pennsylvania had members of their executive councils simultaneously serving as judges. In contrast, many southern states explicitly demanded a separation of powers, with Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia all keeping their government branches "separate and distinct."

Ottoman madrasahs, despite encompassing various fields like calligraphic, oral, and intellectual sciences, fundamentally functioned as Islamic centers for spiritual education. The ultimate aim of all knowledge, especially spiritual disciplines, was to comprehend God. The value and importance of individual sciences were largely dictated by religious principles. As İnalcık noted, sciences benefiting religion were deemed good, while others such as astrology were considered detrimental. Even subjects like mathematics and logic, though included in the madrasah curriculum, were entirely anchored in a religious context; mathematical instruction itself was driven by a religious impetus. The Ulema in Ottoman madrasahs believed it was pointless to oppose logic and mathematics, as these subjects trained the mind for sound reasoning, thereby aiding in the discovery of divine truths. İnalcık further stated that philosophy could only be studied if it served to corroborate Islamic doctrines. Consequently, Ottoman madrasahs essentially operated as religious institutions dedicated to religious instruction and study. While academics like Goffman have posited that the Ottomans were largely tolerant and lived in a pluralistic society, the primary educational institutions—schools—appear to have been profoundly religious, not religiously pluralistic, but rather singularly focused on Islam. A similar pattern emerged in Europe, where "Jewish children learned the Hebrew letters and texts of basic prayers at home, and then attended a school organised by the synagogue to study the Torah." Wiesner-Hanks also observed that Protestants aimed to instill "proper religious values." This indicates a parallel between early modern Ottoman and European perspectives on school administration and primary educational objectives. Therefore, Ottoman madrasahs resembled contemporary schools by offering a broad spectrum of studies; yet, their ultimate purpose was to reinforce and strengthen Islamic practices and theories.

Thuringia boasts a highly varied landscape. Its northernmost part features the Harz mountains, succeeded by the Goldene Aue, a productive floodplain encircling Nordhausen, primarily fed by the Helme river. To the north-west lies the Eichsfeld, an undulating and occasionally wooded area from which the Leine river originates. The central and northern sections of Thuringia are characterized by the 3000 km² Thuringian Basin, an exceptionally fertile and level expanse centered on the Unstrut river and entirely encircled by these hill ranges (listed clockwise from the north-west): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich. Smaller hill chains, specifically Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen, are found within the Basin itself. Directly south of the Thuringian Basin lies the state's most extensive mountain range, delineated by the Thuringian Forest to the north-west, the Thuringian Highland centrally, and the Franconian Forest in the south-east. This range is predominantly forested, and Thuringia's highest peak is the Großer Beerberg (983 m). Towards the south-west, the Forest transitions into the Werra river valley, which separates it from the Rhön Mountains to the west and the Grabfeld plain to the south. Eastern Thuringia, generally defined as the territory east of the Saale and Loquitz valleys, exhibits a hilly topography that gradually ascends from the level north to the mountainous south. The Saale to the west and the Weiße Elster to the east are the two major rivers flowing northwards, carving out heavily populated valleys in this region. Nestled between them are the flat and wooded Holzland in the north, the flat and productive Orlasenke in the center, and the Vogtland, a hilly yet largely deforested area in the south. The easternmost district (east of the Weiße Elster) is the Osterland or Altenburger Land, situated along the Pleiße river, characterized by its flat, rich, and heavily populated agricultural terrain.

During the 14th century, French monarchs aimed to extend their power by diminishing the landholdings of the aristocracy. Their efforts met resistance when they tried to seize the territories held by English kings in southern France, which ignited the Hundred Years' War, lasting from 1337 to 1453. In the initial phase of the conflict, the English, led by Edward III (reigned 1327–77) and his son Edward, the Black Prince (died 1376), triumphed at Crécy and Poitiers, seized Calais, and secured dominion over a significant portion of France. The ensuing pressures nearly led to the collapse of the French kingdom during the war's initial period. France once more faced near dissolution in the early 15th century, but by the late 1420s, the military triumphs of Joan of Arc (died 1431) propelled the French to victory, culminating in the seizure of the final English holdings in southern France by 1453. This came at a considerable cost, as France's population at the conclusion of the wars was estimated to be half its size at the conflict's outset. In contrast, the wars positively shaped English national identity, significantly contributing to the unification of diverse local identities into a shared English ideal. The struggle with France also fostered a distinct national culture in England, diverging from French culture, which had formerly been the prevailing influence. The English longbow rose to prominence early in the Hundred Years' War, and cannons made their battlefield debut at Crécy in 1346.

The Jurassic Period spanned approximately 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 million years ago (Ma). Early in the Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea fragmented into Laurasia (northern) and Gondwana (southern); simultaneously, the Gulf of Mexico emerged within the nascent rift separating North America from the modern-day Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. The North Atlantic Ocean remained comparatively narrow during this period, whereas the South Atlantic did not begin to open until the subsequent Cretaceous Period, as Gondwana itself underwent further rifting. The Tethys Sea receded, giving rise to the Neotethys basin. Climates were generally warm, showing no indications of glacial activity. Similar to the Triassic, there was seemingly no landmass near either pole, precluding the formation of extensive ice caps. Western Europe boasts a robust Jurassic geological record, with widespread marine sequences suggesting much of the continent was submerged beneath shallow tropical seas; notable sites include the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the celebrated late Jurassic lagerstätten at Holzmaden and Solnhofen. Conversely, North America's Jurassic record is the most sparse of the Mesozoic Era, characterized by limited surface outcrops. While the epicontinental Sundance Sea deposited marine sediments across portions of the northern plains of the United States and Canada in the late Jurassic, most exposed sediments from this epoch are continental, exemplified by the alluvial deposits of the Morrison Formation. The mid-Jurassic saw the initial emplacement of several massive batholiths in the northern Cordillera, signifying the onset of the Nevadan orogeny. Significant Jurassic exposures are additionally present in Russia, India, South America, Japan, Australasia, and

Numerous ground personnel at the airport attend to the aircraft. A tow tractor maneuvers the aircraft to an airbridge, where the ground power unit is then connected. This unit supplies electricity to the plane while it is parked at the terminal, as the inactive engines cannot generate power as they would during flight. Passengers exit the aircraft via the airbridge. Mobile stairs provide ground crew with enhanced access to the aircraft's interior. A cleaning service tidies the aircraft following its arrival. Flight catering supplies food and beverages for the journey. A lavatory service truck empties the holding tank containing human waste from the aircraft's toilets. A water truck replenishes the aircraft's water tanks. A fuel transfer vehicle moves aviation fuel from subterranean storage tanks to the aircraft's tanks. A tractor with dollies transports luggage from the terminal to the aircraft. Conversely, they also convey baggage to the terminal when an aircraft has landed and is being unloaded. Hi-loaders elevate heavy luggage containers to the cargo hold's entrance, where ground crew then push them inside. Upon arrival, hi-loaders ascend, ground crew place the container onto it, and it descends. The luggage container is then transferred onto a tractor's dolly. A conveyor belt system mounted on a truck delivers irregularly shaped or delayed baggage. New passengers utilize the airbridge to board the aircraft. The tow tractor then pushes the aircraft from the terminal to a designated taxiing area. The aircraft is expected to depart the airport and be airborne within 90 minutes. The airport levies a fee to the airline based on the duration the aircraft remains on its premises.

The highest religious and political office in Islam, the caliphate, was claimed by the sultans beginning with Murad I, thereby establishing the Ottoman Caliphate. The Ottoman sultan, also known as pâdişâh or "lord of kings," served as the Empire's sole ruler and was seen as the personification of its government, even if his control wasn't consistently absolute. One of the most significant power centers of the Ottoman court was the Imperial Harem, which was governed by the Valide Sultan. Occasionally, the Valide Sultan would become involved in state politics. For a period, the women of the Harem effectively controlled the state, a time known as the "Sultanate of Women." New sultans were always selected from the sons of the preceding sultan. The palace school's robust educational system was designed to remove unsuitable potential heirs and to cultivate support for a successor among the ruling elite. The palace schools, which also educated the state's future administrators, were not monolithic. Firstly, the Madrasa (Ottoman Turkish: Medrese‎) was designated for Muslims, training scholars and state officials in line with Islamic tradition. The financial burden of the Medrese was supported by vakifs, allowing children from poor families to ascend to higher social and economic levels. The second track was the Enderûn, a free boarding school for Christians, which annually recruited 3,000 Christian boys between the ages of eight and twenty from one in forty families among communities settled in Rumelia or the Balkans, a practice known as Devshirme.

Upon acquiring the Master Sword, Link is freed from the wolf-form curse, simultaneously obtaining the Shadow Crystal. Able to switch forms at will using the crystal, Link is guided by Midna to the Mirror of Twilight, deep in the Gerudo Desert and the sole known portal between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule. However, they find the mirror shattered. The Sages explain Zant attempted its destruction but only managed to fragment it; solely the true Twili ruler can utterly destroy the Mirror of Twilight. They also disclose its use a century prior to banish Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who sought the Triforce, to the Twilight Realm after his execution failed. Aided by an underground resistance in Castle Town, Link and Midna seek the Mirror's missing shards, overcoming those it corrupted. With the portal restored, Midna is revealed as the true Twilight Realm ruler, usurped by Zant through a curse changing her form. Confronting Zant, Link and Midna discover his coup resulted from a pact with Ganondorf, who sought Zant's aid in conquering Hyrule. After Link defeats Zant, Midna recovers the Fused Shadows, then destroys Zant, realizing only Ganondorf's demise frees her curse. Returning to Hyrule, Link and Midna find Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle, a lifeless Zelda suspended above him. Ganondorf battles Link by possessing Zelda, then transforming into a beast; Link defeats him, and Midna resurrects Zelda.

Jerusalem holds profound significance for Jews, Muslims, and Christians alike, housing sites central to their faiths, including the Old City with its Western Wall and Temple Mount, the Al-Aqsa Mosque, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. Additional religiously important sites within Israel include Nazareth, revered in Christianity as the location of the Annunciation of Mary; Tiberias and Safed, two of Judaism's Four Holy Cities; Ramla's White Mosque, sacred in Islam as the shrine of Prophet Saleh; and the Church of Saint George in Lod, considered holy by both Christians and Muslims as the tomb of Saint George or Al Khidr. Several other significant religious landmarks are situated in the West Bank, such as Joseph's Tomb in Nablus, the birthplace of Jesus and Rachel's Tomb in Bethlehem, and the Cave of the Patriarchs in Hebron. Haifa's Bahá'í World Centre hosts the administrative hub of the Bahá'í Faith and the Shrine of the Báb; the faith's leader is interred in Acre. While it serves as a pilgrimage destination, Israel has no Bahá'í community beyond its maintenance personnel. Bahá'í staff in the country adhere to a strict policy against teaching their faith to Israelis. Situated a few miles south of the Bahá'í World Centre lies the Middle East center for the reformist Ahmadiyya movement. Its unique neighborhood, comprising both Jews and Ahmadi Arabs, stands as the sole example of its kind nationwide.

Major conference realignment led to changes in Notre Dame's conference affiliations for all sports except football and fencing in July 2013; its fencing affiliation will shift in July 2014. The Irish departed the Big East for the ACC amidst a lengthy period of Big East instability. While retaining football independence, they agreed to play five games annually against ACC adversaries. For ice hockey, the Irish had to secure a new conference after the Big Ten's 2013–14 addition of the sport triggered a series of conference shifts, ultimately dissolving the Central Collegiate Hockey Association, the school's previous hockey league, following the 2012–13 season. Consequently, Notre Dame transitioned its hockey team to Hockey East. Following Notre Dame's entry into the ACC, the conference declared it would introduce fencing as a sponsored sport starting with the 2014–15 academic year. While various theories surround the athletics moniker's adoption, the "Fighting Irish" name was notably applied to the football team in the early 1920s and gained prominence through alumnus Francis Wallace's New York Daily News columns. Navy Blue and Gold Rush serve as Notre Dame's official colors, featured in competition by its athletic squads. Additionally, green is frequently incorporated into uniforms, referencing the "Fighting Irish" nickname. The Notre Dame Leprechaun functions as the athletic teams' official mascot. Conceived by Theodore W. Drake in 1964, the leprechaun initially appeared on the football pocket schedule before gracing football program covers. Its appearance on the cover of Time in November 1964 brought it national recognition.

In 1718, Cotton Mather reached out to Elihu Yale, a prosperous businessman residing in Wales, though born in Boston to one of New Haven's initial settlers, David Yale. This outreach, prompted by either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, sought financial assistance to erect a new college structure. Persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had amassed considerable wealth through trade as an East India Company representative in Madras, contributed nine bales of merchandise. These were subsequently sold for more than £560, a significant sum for the era. Cotton Mather then put forth the idea of renaming the institution Yale College. Simultaneously, an alumnus of Harvard working in England convinced approximately 180 prominent intellectuals to gift books to Yale. The 1714 consignment of 500 volumes represented the pinnacle of contemporary English literature, science, philosophy, and theology, profoundly affecting Yale's scholars. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards, for instance, encountered John Locke's writings and formulated his distinctive theological system, dubbed the "new divinity." By 1722, the Rector and six companions from a discussion group, having explored these novel concepts, announced their departure from Calvinism, embrace of Arminianism, and affiliation with the Church of England. They underwent ordination in England before returning to the colonies as proponents of the Anglican faith. Upon becoming president in 1745, Thomas Clapp endeavored to steer the college back toward Calvinist orthodoxy, yet he maintained the library's accessibility. Notably, other students later found Deist texts within its collection.

Despite efforts to revitalize Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, it is not widely known by Jews globally, and English has emerged as the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora. While many Jews once possessed sufficient Hebrew knowledge to study classical literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were commonly used as recently as the early 20th century, most contemporary Jews lack such proficiency, and English has largely superseded most Jewish vernaculars. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today are Hebrew, English, and Russian. Some Romance languages, particularly French and Spanish, are also widely used. Yiddish was historically spoken by more Jews than any other language, but its usage has significantly decreased following the Holocaust and the adoption of Modern Hebrew by the Zionist movement and the State of Israel. In some locations, the mother tongue of the Jewish community differs from that of the general population or the dominant group. For example, in Quebec, the Ashkenazic majority has adopted English, while the Sephardic minority uses French as its primary language. Similarly, South African Jews adopted English rather than Afrikaans. Due to both Czarist and Soviet policies, Russian has replaced Yiddish as the language of Russian Jews, and these policies have also influenced neighboring communities. Today, Russian is the primary language for many Jewish communities in several Post-Soviet states, such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan, as well as for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Although North African Jewish communities are currently small and declining, Jews there shifted from being multilingual to largely monolingual, speaking French in Algeria, Morocco, and the city of Tunis, while most North Africans continue to use Arabic as their mother tongue.

The territory now known as Galicia was first settled by humans during the Middle Paleolithic era, deriving its name from the Gallaeci, Celtic groups who inhabited the region north of the Douro river during the final millennium BC, in an area largely corresponding to the local Iron Age Castro culture. Galicia was integrated into the Roman Empire following the conclusion of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, subsequently becoming a Roman province in the 3rd century AD. In 410, the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with its capital in Braga (Portugal), which was absorbed by the Visigoths in 585. While the Arabs invaded the Iberian Peninsula and conquered the Visigothic kingdom in 711, Galicia was soon incorporated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias by 740. Throughout the Middle Ages, the kingdom of Galicia was occasionally governed by its own monarchs, though it was predominantly allied with the kingdom of Leon and later with Castile, yet it preserved its distinct legal, customary, and cultural identity. From the 13th century onward, Castilian kings, acting as kings of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór, whose responsibilities were transferred to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galicia from the late 15th century. This Governor also presided over the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, which functioned as both a royal tribunal and a governmental body. Beginning in the 16th century, the kingdom's representation and voice were embodied by the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, an assembly of deputies and representatives from the kingdom's cities; this institution was forcibly dissolved in 1833 when the kingdom was fragmented into four administratively separate provinces with no legal connections. The 19th and 20th centuries witnessed an increasing demand for Galician self-governance and the recognition of its unique identity, culminating in the unsuccessful Statute of Autonomy of 1936 and the currently active Statute of Autonomy of 1981.

Avian respiratory systems excel at oxygen diffusion into the bloodstream, boasting a gas exchange surface area ten times larger relative to volume compared to mammals. This efficiency means birds possess a higher concentration of blood within their lung capillaries per unit of lung volume than their mammalian counterparts. Arteries, built with thick, elastic muscle walls, are designed to endure the force of ventricular contraction, gradually stiffening further from the heart. Blood flows through these arteries, which constrict as needed, then into arterioles. These arterioles serve as a vital transport network, delivering oxygen primarily, alongside nutrients, throughout the body's tissues. Progressing from the heart into specific organs and tissues, arterioles branch extensively, thereby increasing their surface area and reducing blood velocity. From the arterioles, blood enters the capillaries, the primary sites for gas exchange. Within tissues, capillaries form intricate beds where oxygen is traded for carbon dioxide waste, and blood flow decelerates significantly to maximize oxygen diffusion into the surrounding cells. After deoxygenation, blood proceeds through venules and subsequently veins, making its way back to the heart. In contrast to arteries, veins are characterized by their thin, less elastic structure, as they are not subjected to the intense pressures of arterial circulation. As blood moves from venules into veins, a process of vasodilation, or widening, facilitates its return toward the heart. Upon reaching the heart, blood first enters the right atrium, then the right ventricle, from where it is propelled to the lungs for the exchange of carbon dioxide waste for fresh oxygen. The now-oxygenated blood returns from the lungs, passing through the left atrium to the left ventricle, ready to be powerfully circulated throughout the rest of the body.

Roc-A-Fella Records officially released The College Dropout in February 2004, which quickly ascended to number two on the Billboard 200. Its debut single, "Through the Wire," concurrently peaked at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for five weeks. His second single, "Slow Jamz," featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, proved even more successful, becoming the first number one hit for all three musicians. The College Dropout received widespread critical acclaim from contemporary music critics, was recognized as the top album of the year by two major music publications, and has consistently been ranked among significant hip-hop works and impactful debut albums by artists. "Jesus Walks," the album's fourth single, arguably introduced West to a larger audience, given its subject matter on faith and Christianity. Despite industry executives' skepticism that a song with such overt religious declarations would gain radio traction, it still reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts. The College Dropout ultimately achieved triple platinum certification in the US and earned West 10 Grammy nominations, including Album of the Year and a win for Best Rap Album. During this era, West also founded GOOD Music, a record label and management company that would eventually sign affiliated artists and producers such as No I.D. and John Legend. At the time, West's production style was primarily defined by the use of sped-up vocal samples sourced from soul records. However, partly due to The College Dropout's acclaim, this sampling approach was widely emulated; with this overuse, and West's own sense of becoming too reliant on the technique, he resolved to develop a new sound.

As Nimitz had foreseen, the Japanese fleet reached Midway on June 4th, detected by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo initiated a first strike against Midway, while Fletcher launched his own aircraft towards Nagumo's carriers. At 09:20, the first U.S. carrier planes, TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet, arrived, but their attacks were poorly coordinated and ineffectual; partly due to faulty aerial torpedoes, they failed to land a single hit, and all 15 were annihilated by defending Zero fighters. By 09:35, 15 more TBDs from Enterprise attacked, with 14 being lost, again without any hits. Though Fletcher's attacks had been disorganized and seemingly unproductive so far, they successfully drew Nagumo's defensive fighters down to sea level, where they expended much of their fuel and ammunition repelling the two waves of torpedo bombers. Consequently, when U.S. dive bombers appeared at high altitude, the Zeros were poorly positioned to defend. To exacerbate matters, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation while evading torpedoes, thereby reducing the concentration of their anti-aircraft fire. Nagumo's indecision also created chaos aboard his carriers. Alerted to the need for a second strike on Midway, but also apprehensive about engaging the American carriers he now knew were nearby, Nagumo twice modified the arming orders for his aircraft. As a result, American dive bombers found the Japanese carriers with their decks cluttered with munitions as crews hastily worked to properly re-arm their air groups.

Vladimir served as the prince of Novgorod when his father, Sviatoslav I, passed away in 972. In 976, he was compelled to escape to Scandinavia after his half-brother Yaropolk assassinated their brother Oleg and seized control of Rus. While in Scandinavia, Vladimir, aided by his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, Norway's ruler, gathered a Viking force and successfully reclaimed Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk. As the Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's most significant accomplishment was initiating the Christianization of Kievan Rus' in 988. According to The Primary Chronicle, upon deciding to adopt a new faith over the traditional Slavic idol-worship (paganism), Vladimir dispatched several esteemed advisors and warriors as emissaries across various European regions. Their journey took them to Latin Rite Christians, Jews, and Muslims before their eventual arrival in Constantinople. They dismissed Islam partly due to its alcohol prohibition, and Judaism because its God allowed his chosen people to lose their land. The Roman church's ceremonies, they observed, lacked vibrancy. However, in Constantinople, the grandeur of the Hagia Sophia cathedral and its liturgical service so deeply impressed them that they immediately resolved on the faith they wished to embrace. Returning home, they persuaded Vladimir that the Byzantine Rite faith was superior, prompting him to journey to Constantinople and arrange marriage to Princess Anna, sister of Byzantine Emperor Basil II.

Adolescence represents a critical period for identity development, with most individuals commencing this journey during these formative years. During this time, adolescents frequently explore various behaviors and appearances, effectively trying on different identities to discover who they are and find one that best suits them. However, establishing and maintaining an identity in adolescence is a complex endeavor, influenced by numerous factors such such as family life, environment, and social standing. Empirical studies suggest that this process is more accurately termed "identity development" rather than "formation," confirming a normative progression of change in both the content and structure of one's thoughts about the self. The two primary facets of identity development are self-clarity and self-esteem. Since choices made during adolescent years can significantly impact later life, strong self-awareness and self-control during mid-adolescence are linked to better decisions during the transition to adulthood. Researchers typically utilize three main approaches to understanding identity development: self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem. The adolescent years contribute to the emergence of a more conscientious group of young adults. Adolescents dedicate considerable attention and effort to their appearance as their bodies undergo changes, actively striving to look presentable, unlike younger children. The environment in which an adolescent matures also plays a vital role in their identity development. Research by the American Psychological Association indicates that adolescents from less privileged backgrounds often encounter greater challenges in establishing their identity.

Athanasius stated he was a student, receiving instruction from individuals martyred during the Great (tenth) and final persecution of Christianity by pagan Rome. This persecution was most severe in the East, particularly in Egypt and Palestine. Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop, was executed in 311 towards the end of this persecution and may have been one of Athanasius's teachers. Alexander of Alexandria (312–328), who succeeded Peter as bishop, was an Origenist and a documented mentor to Athanasius. According to Sozomen, Bishop Alexander "invited Athanasius to live with him and serve as his secretary. Athanasius was highly educated, skilled in grammar and rhetoric, and even as a young man, before becoming a bishop, demonstrated his wisdom and sharpness to those around him." Athanasius's initial work, *Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation* (composed before 319), shows influences of Origenist Alexandrian philosophy (such as frequent citations of Plato and a definition from Aristotle's *Organon*), yet maintained an orthodox perspective. He was also conversant with the ideas of diverse philosophical traditions, particularly the advancements in Neo-Platonism. Ultimately, Athanasius would steer the philosophical approach of the School of Alexandria away from Origenist tenets, such as the "entirely allegorical interpretation of the text." Nevertheless, in subsequent writings, Athanasius quotes Homer on multiple occasions (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29). His letter to Emperor Constantius features a self-defense that clearly reflects his study of Demosthenes' *de Corona*.

Adolescent egocentrism cultivates a self-aware drive for importance among peers and a longing for social acceptance. In contrast to the often contradictory elements of self-concept, identity signifies a unified self-perception that remains consistent through various situations, encompassing both past experiences and future aspirations. While everyone possesses a self-concept, Erik Erikson contended that not all individuals fully attain identity. Erikson's developmental stage theory features the identity crisis, a period where adolescents are required to investigate diverse possibilities and synthesize various facets of their being prior to solidifying their convictions. He characterized the successful navigation of this process as "identity achievement" yet also emphasized that the identity pursuit "is never fully resolved once and for all at one point in time." Initially, adolescents define themselves primarily through their affiliation with specific social groups. "Clothes help teens explore new identities, separate from parents, and bond with peers." Fashion has been instrumental in adolescents' "finding their selves"; its constant evolution mirrors the developing changes in teenage personalities. Teenagers strive to establish their identity by deliberately adopting various styles to discover what resonates most with them. Through a process of trial and error, aligning their self-perception with how others perceive and react to them, adolescents gain a clearer understanding of their own identity. The media, much like fashion, is also continually evolving to influence adolescents. "Modern life takes place amidst a never-ending barrage of flesh on screens, pages, and billboards." This constant exposure, whether conscious or subconscious, impacts the mind, leading to self-image concerns that influence an adolescent's developing sense of identity. Researcher James Marcia devised the prevailing methodology for assessing an individual's advancement through these stages. His questions are categorized into three areas: occupation, ideology, and interpersonal relationships. Responses are evaluated based on the depth of exploration undertaken by the individual and the firmness of their commitments. This results in classifying individuals into: a) identity diffusion, the initial stage for all children; b) Identity Foreclosure, where commitments are established without exploring alternatives; c) Moratorium, which represents the active process of exploration; or d) Identity Achievement, indicating that Moratorium has concluded and commitments have been formed.

Stanley Schachter developed his theory building upon the prior research of Spanish doctor Gregorio Marañón, who administered epinephrine injections to patients and then inquired about their sensations. Notably, Marañón observed that while most patients reported feeling *something*, without a genuine emotion-triggering event, they could not define their physiological state as a specific emotion. Schachter concurred that physiological responses were crucial to emotions. He proposed that these reactions aided emotional experience by enabling a deliberate cognitive interpretation of a specific physiologically stimulating occurrence, and this interpretation shaped the subjective feeling of emotion. Consequently, emotions emerged from a two-step process: generalized physiological stimulation followed by the conscious experience of an emotion. For instance, consider the physiological arousal of a pounding heart in response to a stimulus like seeing a bear in the kitchen. The brain rapidly assesses the surroundings to account for this physical sensation, identifying the bear. As a result, the brain interprets the rapid heartbeat as an outcome of fearing the bear. Alongside his student, Jerome Singer, Schachter illustrated that individuals could exhibit varied emotional responses even when induced into an identical physiological state via an epinephrine injection. Participants were seen to display either anger or amusement, contingent on whether another individual present (a confederate) exhibited that particular emotion. Thus, the emotional reaction was determined by the interplay between the cognitive evaluation of the situation and the participants' physiological state, whether from adrenaline or a placebo. Jesse Prinz's 2004 work, *Gut Reactions*, includes criticism of this experiment.

Hong Taiji's administration incorporated numerous Han Chinese, including many former Ming officials who had recently surrendered. Manchu preeminence was sustained through an ethnic quota for senior bureaucratic appointments. Hong Taiji's reign also marked a fundamental reorientation of policy regarding his Han Chinese subjects. Nurhaci had previously distinguished Han in Liaodong based on their grain holdings; those with fewer than 5 to 7 sin were treated as chattel, while those with more were granted property. Following a Han revolt in Liaodong in 1623, Nurhaci, who had previously offered concessions to conquered Han subjects in the region, turned against them, declaring them untrustworthy. He instituted discriminatory policies and carried out killings against them, while simultaneously ordering that Han who had assimilated into Jurchen culture (in Jilin) before 1619 be treated equally as Jurchens, unlike the conquered Han in Liaodong. Hong Taiji, by contrast, integrated them into the Jurchen "nation" as full, though not necessarily first-class, citizens, obligating them to provide military service. By 1648, less than one-sixth of the bannermen were of Manchu descent. This shift in policy not only increased Hong Taiji's available manpower and reduced his military reliance on banners not under his direct command, but it also strongly encouraged other Han Chinese subjects of the Ming dynasty to surrender and accept Jurchen rule when militarily defeated. Through these and other initiatives, Hong Taiji successfully centralized power in the office of the Khan, which ultimately prevented the Jurchen federation from fragmenting after his death.

The tech media outlet CNET awarded the new Super Slim 4 out of 5 stars, labeling it "Excellent." The review highlighted how the console condenses a robust gaming machine into an even smaller design, while retaining the strong gaming library and array of streaming services found in its predecessors. Conversely, CNET criticized the "cheap" feel of its design and disc-loader. They noted that the cover sometimes "doesn't catch," likening the experience to using "old credit card imprinter machines," concluding it "feels cheap" and that the absence of convenient autoloading disc trays represented a "step back," whether for cost or space reasons. Price was another point of contention, as the most affordable Super Slim model was still pricier than the cheapest Slim, and the reduced size and larger hard drive weren't considered a significant upgrade given the ease with which a Slim model's hard drive could be removed and replaced. However, CNET did commend the Super Slim's hard drive accessibility as "the easiest yet," noting that "simply sliding off the side panel reveals the drive bay, which can quickly be unscrewed." While not an upgrade, the review suggested the Super Slim could be indicative of future trends. They concluded that while "not revolutionary," the Super Slim PS3 is the "same impressive machine in a much smaller package," offering no compelling reason for current PS3 owners to upgrade, but advising prospective PS3 buyers to opt for the Super Slim if they could tolerate the manual disc loading.

Y-DNA investigations tend to indicate a limited number of male progenitors in an ancient population, whose descendants subsequently diverged and pursued distinct migratory routes. For most Jewish communities, these paternal line ancestors predominantly appear to have been Middle Eastern. For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with non-Jewish populations in the regions of Eastern Europe, Germany, and the French Rhine Valley where Jews historically resided. This observation aligns with Jewish traditions that place the majority of Jewish paternal origins in the Middle East. Conversely, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, examined through mitochondrial DNA, generally exhibit greater heterogeneity. Scholars such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk propose that this suggests many Jewish males acquired new partners from European and other communities in the various diaspora locations they migrated to after departing ancient Israel. In contrast, Behar's findings revealed that approximately 40% of Ashkenazi Jews maternally descend from merely four female founders, who were of Middle Eastern origin. The populations of Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities, however, "showed no evidence for a narrow founder effect" in their maternal lines.
