Subsequent studies conducted by Feder et al. confirmed the substantial proportion of non-local maternal ancestry among Ashkenazi Jews. Reflecting on their discoveries related to the maternal origins of Ashkenazi Jews, the authors concluded, "Clearly, the differences between Jews and non-Jews are far larger than those observed among the Jewish communities. Hence, differences between the Jewish communities can be overlooked when non-Jews are included in

The state collectively endorsed the Plan of Ayutla, subsequently ratifying the new constitution in 1855. Thanks to its numerous liberal political figures, the state weathered the Reform War incurring only minimal damage. Even a successful 1858 military campaign by conservative Zuloaga, whose 1,000 men occupied Chihuahua and Parral, failed to establish the conservative movement in the state. Liberal Orozco and his forces defeated Zuloaga's contingent in August 1859; Orozco then unseated the state governor, though he himself was forced to flee to Durango just two months later. Following a campaign through Jalisco in the late 1860s, conservative General Cajen briefly entered the state, facilitating the rise of conservative politicians and expelling liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. Cajen seized the state capital, declared himself governor, and swiftly amassed a substantial force to confront and defeat liberal opposition at La Batalla del Gallo. While Cajen initially gained several advantages over liberals in the state, his position quickly eroded as liberal forces experienced a strong resurgence. The ascendant liberal leaders, José María Patoni from Durango and J.E. Muñoz from Chihuahua, swiftly solidified their authority by enforcing a presidential decree that curtailed the political rights of the clergy. The state then elected liberal General Luis Terrazas as governor, who would spend 1861 engaging in minor internal skirmishes to quell conservative uprisings.

Modern teenagers encounter various risks as their sexuality begins to mature. While some of these, such as emotional distress (arising from fear of abuse or exploitation) and sexually transmitted infections/diseases (STIs/STDs), including HIV/AIDS, are not exclusive to adolescence, others like teenage pregnancy (due to non-use or failure of contraceptives) are widely viewed as social problems in most Western nations. A quarter of sexually active adolescents will contract an STI. Adolescents in the United States frequently opt for non-intercourse sexual activities, mistakenly believing this reduces STI risks. Nationwide, clinicians report rising diagnoses of herpes and human papillomavirus (HPV), which causes genital warts and is now thought to affect 15% of the teen population. Girls aged 15 to 19 have higher gonorrhea rates than any other age group. One-quarter of all new HIV cases occur in individuals under 21. Multrine’s article also notes that a March survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation revealed 81% of parents want schools to discuss condom and contraception use with their children. These parents also believe students should have access to STI testing. Furthermore, teachers themselves wish to address such topics with their students. However, despite 90% of sex education instructors nationwide believing students should be taught about contraceptives in school, over a quarter report receiving explicit instructions from school boards and administrators prohibiting it. According to anthropologist Margaret Mead, the turmoil observed in Western adolescent society is culturally, rather than physically, induced; she reported that societies where young women engaged in free sexual activity exhibited no such adolescent unrest.

Bermuda's population's deeper ancestral makeup is indistinct due to the ethnic homogenization that has occurred over the past four centuries. Presently, there is virtually no ethnic differentiation between black and white Bermudians, apart from what defines more recent immigrant groups. This situation was markedly different in the 17th century. During the initial century of settlement, white Protestants of English descent constituted a clear majority. White minority groups included Irish (many likely Gaelic speakers) and Scots, who were transported to Bermuda following the English invasions of their respective homelands after the English Civil War. Non-white minorities comprised Spanish-speaking, free (indentured) black individuals from the West Indies; black chattel slaves, mostly seized from Spanish and Portuguese vessels by Bermudian privateers; and Native Americans, predominantly from Algonquian and other Atlantic seaboard tribes, with some potentially originating from Mexico. By the 19th century, the numerically dominant position of white ethnically-English Bermudians had diminished. Despite prohibitions on Irish immigration and persistent efforts to compel free blacks to emigrate and slave owners to export their slaves, the amalgamation of diverse minority groups, together with some white English individuals, led to the formation of a new demographic, "coloured" Bermudians (a term in Bermuda denoting anyone not exclusively of European descent), who achieved a slight majority. Any offspring born before or after that period to one coloured and one white parent was counted within the coloured demographic. Today, most individuals historically categorized as "coloured" are identified as "black" or "of African heritage," a classification that tends to overlook their non-African ancestry. Although non-African "coloured" individuals were historically few, the population of South Asians, in particular, is currently expanding, evidenced by the doubling of Asian-born persons between the 2000 and 2010 censuses. Throughout these changes, blacks have maintained their majority status, with new white immigration from Portugal, Britain, and other regions being counterbalanced by black immigration from the West Indies.

An individual's immune response to antigens is influenced by their age, the specific antigen type, maternal factors, and the site of antigen presentation. Newborns are considered to be in a state of physiological immunodeficiency because both their innate and adaptive immune responses are significantly suppressed. After birth, an infant's immune system responds effectively to protein antigens but less efficiently to glycoproteins and polysaccharides. Consequently, many infections acquired by neonates are caused by low-virulence organisms like Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas.

Neonates exhibit very limited opsonic activity and a reduced capacity to activate the complement cascade. For instance, the average C3 level in a newborn is approximately 65% of that found in an adult. Phagocytic activity is also substantially impaired in newborns. This is attributed to lower opsonic activity, as well as diminished up-regulation of integrin and selectin receptors, which restricts the ability of neutrophils to interact with adhesion molecules in the endothelium. Their monocytes are slow and have reduced ATP production, further limiting the newborn's phagocytic activity. Although the total number of lymphocytes is significantly higher than in adults, both cellular and humoral immunity are also compromised. Antigen-presenting cells in newborns have a reduced capability to activate T cells. Additionally, neonatal T cells proliferate poorly and produce very small amounts of cytokines such as IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-12, and IFN-g, which limits their capacity to activate both the humoral response and the phagocytic activity of macrophages. While B cells develop early during gestation, they are not fully active.

Veteran artists like Aerosmith sustained their commercial achievements, notably with their multi-platinum, chart-topping albums Get a Grip (1993) and Nine Lives (1997). Get a Grip spawned four Top 40 singles and became the band's top-selling album globally, exceeding 10 million copies sold. In 1998, Aerosmith released the number one hit "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing," which remains the only single by a hard rock band to debut at number one. AC/DC also produced the double-platinum Ballbreaker (1995). Bon Jovi appealed to their hard rock audience with songs like "Keep the Faith" (1992) and also found success in adult contemporary radio with the Top 10 ballads "Bed of Roses" (1993) and "Always" (1994). Bon Jovi's 1995 album These Days proved more popular in Europe than in the United States, generating four Top 10 singles on the UK Singles Chart. Metallica's Load (1996) and ReLoad (1997) each sold more than 4 million copies in the US and marked the band's development of a more melodic and blues rock sound. As the initial drive of grunge bands diminished in the mid-decade, post-grunge bands emerged. They mimicked the attitudes and sound of grunge, particularly its thick, distorted guitars, but with a more radio-friendly, commercially oriented sound that drew more directly from traditional hard rock. Among the most successful were the Foo Fighters, Candlebox, Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair, and England's Bush, all of whom cemented post-grunge as one of the most commercially viable subgenres by the late 1990s. Similarly, some post-Britpop acts that followed Oasis, including Feeder and Stereophonics, adopted a hard rock or "pop-metal" style.

A 2002 Guardian article highlighted a government report, revealing that from 1940 to 1979, the Ministry of Defence (MoD) "transformed significant areas of the nation into a vast laboratory to conduct clandestine germ warfare experiments on its citizens." Many of these experiments "entailed dispersing potentially hazardous chemicals and micro-organisms across extensive segments of the populace without their knowledge or consent." The MoD asserts that these exercises aimed to simulate germ warfare and were innocuous. Nevertheless, families residing in regions affected by numerous tests report children born with birth defects, as well as physical and mental disabilities, prompting widespread calls for a public inquiry. The report suggests these trials impacted an estimated millions, with one specific period between 1961 and 1968 exposing "over a million individuals along England's south coast, stretching from Torquay to the New Forest, to bacteria such as E.coli and bacillus globigii, the latter mimicking anthrax." Two scientists appointed by the Ministry of Defence affirmed that these trials presented no public health risk. Sue Ellison, a Porton Down representative, corroborated this, stating that the outcomes of these trials "will be life-saving if the country or our forces ever encounter a chemical and biological weapons attack." When questioned about the continuation of such tests, she responded: "It is against our policy to discuss research that is currently in progress." Whether the benign nature of these trials was understood at the time they took place remains unknown.

Like reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, meaning their kidneys remove nitrogenous waste from the bloodstream, expelling it as uric acid into the intestine via the ureters, rather than as urea or ammonia. They lack a urinary bladder or an external urethral opening; consequently, uric acid (except in ostriches) is discharged alongside feces as a semisolid substance. However, some birds, such as hummingbirds, can be facultatively ammonotelic, secreting most nitrogenous waste as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, unlike mammals which excrete creatinine. This waste material, along with the contents of the intestines, exits the bird's body through the cloaca. The cloaca serves multiple purposes: it expels waste, is used for mating by cloacal kiss in most species, and is the exit point for eggs in females. Additionally, many bird species regurgitate pellets. Males in certain groups possess a penis: Palaeognathae (excluding kiwis), Anseriformes (excluding screamers), and rudimentary forms in Galliformes (though fully developed in Cracidae), but it is entirely absent in Neoaves. Its length is believed to correlate with sperm competition. When not engaged in copulation, it remains concealed within the proctodeum compartment of the cloaca, just inside the vent. The avian digestive system is distinctive, featuring a crop for food storage and a gizzard containing ingested stones to grind food, compensating for their lack of teeth. Most birds are highly adapted for swift digestion, which assists in flight. Some migratory birds have evolved to utilize protein from various bodily sources, including their intestines, for supplemental energy during migration.

Concerning the timing of a German-Soviet rapprochement, many historians concur that Maxim Litvinov's removal from office, given his Jewish background was seen as a hindrance by Nazi Germany, cleared the path for talks with Germany. Stalin promptly instructed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Considering Litvinov's earlier efforts to forge an anti-fascist alliance, his alignment with collective security alongside France and Britain, and his pro-Western stance by Kremlin standards, his ousting signaled the USSR's potential for a rapprochement with Germany. Similarly, Molotov's appointment conveyed to Germany that the Soviet Union was receptive to proposals. This dismissal also indicated to France and Britain that a possible negotiation channel with Germany existed. A British official noted that Litvinov's departure also signified the loss of a skilled technician or mediator, whereas Molotov's "modus operandi" was "more genuinely Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr posited that the Soviet Union's replacement of Litvinov with Molotov as Foreign Minister on May 3, 1939, did not represent an irreversible move towards an alliance with Germany, but instead was Stalin's tactic for tough negotiations with Britain and France, achieved by placing a famously tough individual, Molotov, in the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis observed that Litvinov's dismissal afforded the Soviets the liberty to accelerate German negotiations, but without abandoning discussions with Britain and France. Derek Watson contended that Molotov was better positioned to secure a favorable agreement with Britain and France as he was unburdened by the concept of collective security and could also engage in talks with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts suggested that Litvinov's removal aided Soviet discussions with Britain and France, as Litvinov reportedly harbored doubts or even opposition towards such

The Guangxu Emperor died on November 14, 1908, followed by Cixi's death the next day, November 15, 1908. Rumors circulated that she or Yuan Shikai had ordered trusted eunuchs to poison the Guangxu Emperor, a claim later confirmed by an autopsy conducted nearly a century afterward, which found lethal levels of arsenic in his corpse. Puyi, the eldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and nephew to the childless Guangxu Emperor, was appointed successor at the age of two, with Zaifeng taking on the regency. This was subsequently followed by the dismissal of General Yuan Shikai from his previous powerful positions. In April 1911, Zaifeng created a cabinet that included two vice-premiers. However, this cabinet was also known by contemporaries as "The Royal Cabinet" because five of its thirteen members were either from the imperial family or Aisin Gioro relatives. This composition drew widespread negative opinions from senior officials like Zhang Zhidong. The Wuchang Uprising of October 10, 1911, led to the establishment of a new central government, the Republic of China, in Nanjing, with Sun Yat-sen as its provisional head. Many provinces soon began to "separate" from Qing control. Facing a desperate situation, the Qing government reinstated Yuan Shikai to military power. He took command of his Beiyang Army to crush the revolution in Wuhan at the Battle of Yangxia. After assuming the position of Prime Minister and forming his own cabinet, Yuan Shikai went as far as to request Zaifeng's removal from the regency. This removal later proceeded under directions from Empress Dowager Longyu.

As a boy, Arnold Schwarzenegger engaged in various sports, significantly influenced by his father. He first lifted a barbell in 1960, when his soccer coach took the team to a local gym. At 14, he chose bodybuilding over soccer as his career path. When questioned about starting weightlifting at 13, Schwarzenegger clarified, "I actually started weight training when I was 15, but I'd been participating in sports, like soccer, for years, so I felt that although I was slim, I was well-developed, at least enough so that I could start going to the gym and start Olympic lifting." However, his official website biography states: "At 14, he started an intensive training program with Dan Farmer, studied psychology at 15 (to learn more about the power of mind over body) and at 17, officially started his competitive career." During a 2001 speech, he revealed, "My own plan formed when I was 14 years old. My father had wanted me to be a police officer like he was. My mother wanted me to go to trade school." Schwarzenegger frequented a gym in Graz and also visited local movie theaters to watch bodybuilding idols such as Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller on the big screen. Following Reeves's death in 2000, Schwarzenegger fondly remembered him, saying: "As a teenager, I grew up with Steve Reeves. His remarkable accomplishments allowed me a sense of what was possible, when others around me didn't always understand my dreams. Steve Reeves has been part of everything I've ever been fortunate enough to achieve." In 1961, Schwarzenegger met former Mr. Austria Kurt Marnul, who invited him to train at the Graz gym. His dedication as a youngster was so profound that he would break into the local gym on weekends, when it was typically closed, just to train. He admitted, "It would make me sick to miss a workout... I knew I couldn't look at myself in the mirror the next morning if I didn't do it." When asked about his first movie experience as a boy, Schwarzenegger replied: "I was very young, but I remember my father taking me to the Austrian theaters and seeing some newsreels. The first real movie I saw, that I distinctly remember, was a John Wayne movie."

During the 1930s, the region saw the construction of its first two motorways: the A4, serving as a vital east-west link in central Germany and the primary connection between Berlin and Germany's southwest, and the A9, which became the main north-south route in eastern Germany, linking Berlin with Munich. The A4 stretches from Frankfurt in Hesse, traversing through Thuringia's key cities including Eisenach, Gotha, Erfurt, Weimar, Jena, and Gera, before reaching Dresden in Saxony, and connects with the A9 at Hermsdorf junction. Both highways underwent expansion from four to six lanes (three in each direction) after 1990, involving significant re-routing in areas like Eisenach and Jena.

Subsequently, three additional motorways were developed between the 1990s and 2000s. The A71 crosses the Land in a southwest-northeast direction, connecting Würzburg in Bavaria with Sangerhausen and Halle in Saxony-Anhalt, passing through Meiningen, Suhl, Ilmenau, Arnstadt, Erfurt, and Sömmerda. Its section through the Thuringian Forest, featuring numerous tunnels (including Germany's longest road tunnel, the Rennsteig Tunnel) and large bridges, ranks among Germany's most expensive motorway segments. The A73 commences at the A71 south of Erfurt in Suhl and extends southwards towards Nuremberg in Bavaria. Another west-east arterial, the A38, runs across northern Thuringia from Göttingen in Lower Saxony, via Heiligenstadt and Nordhausen, to Leipzig in Saxony. Complementing this motorway network is a dense system of federal highways. The 2015 Federal Trunk Road Programme prioritizes the upgrade of these federal highways, with planned projects including improvements to the B247 from Gotha to Leinefelde for better access to Mühlhausen, the B19 from Eisenach to Meiningen to enhance connectivity for Bad Salzungen and Schmalkalden, and the B88 and B281 to bolster the Saalfeld/Rudolstadt region.

Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once chosen, a priest possessed permanent religious authority derived from the eternal divine, which afforded him lifetime influence, privilege, and immunity. Therefore, civil and religious statutes limited the number and type of religious offices an individual and their family could hold. Religious law was collegial and traditional; it guided political decisions, could overturn them, and proved difficult to exploit for personal gain. Priesthood was a costly honour: in customary Roman practice, a priest received no stipend. Cult donations were the property of the deity, and its priest was obliged to provide cult services regardless of shortfalls in public funding – this could necessitate subsidizing acolytes and all other cult maintenance from personal funds. For those who had achieved their goal in the Cursus honorum, a permanent priesthood was ideally sought or granted after a lifetime's service in military or political life, or preferably both: it represented a particularly honourable and active form of retirement that fulfilled an essential public duty. For a freedman or slave, promotion as one of the Compitalia seviri offered a high local profile, opening opportunities in local politics, and consequently, business. During the Imperial era, priesthood of the Imperial cult offered provincial elites full Roman citizenship and public prominence beyond their single year in religious office; in effect, it marked the first step in a provincial cursus honorum. In Rome, the same Imperial cult role was performed by the Arval Brethren, originally an obscure Republican priesthood dedicated to several deities, then integrated by Augustus as part of his religious reforms. The Arvals offered prayer and sacrifice to Roman state gods at various temples for the continued welfare of the Imperial family on their birthdays, accession anniversaries, and to mark extraordinary events such as the quashing of conspiracy or revolt. Every January 3, they consecrated the annual vows and rendered any sacrifice promised in the previous year, provided the gods had kept the Imperial

When Nintendo launched the NES in the US, its aesthetic design diverged intentionally from that of other game consoles. Nintendo aimed to differentiate its offering from rivals and distance itself from the negative image consoles had acquired following the video game market collapse of 1983. One outcome of this approach was the cartridge slot being concealed as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) socket, reminiscent of a VCR's loading mechanism. Initially, this newly designed connector performed effectively when both it and the cartridges were clean, and its pins were new. However, the ZIF connector wasn't genuinely zero insertion force. When users inserted a cartridge, the force of pressing it down and into place slightly bent the contact pins and pushed the cartridge's ROM board inward. Frequent insertion and removal over time caused the pins to wear out, and the ZIF design proved more susceptible to dirt and dust interference than an industry-standard card edge connector. These design issues were exacerbated by Nintendo's material choices; the console slot's nickel connector springs deteriorated, and the game cartridge's copper connectors were prone to tarnishing. Many players attempted to resolve game problems caused by this corrosion by blowing into cartridges before reinserting them, which ironically damaged the copper connectors further by accelerating tarnishing.

In Homer's Iliad, the names Danaans (or Danaoi: Δαναοί) and Argives (Αργείοι) are employed to identify the Greek forces opposing the Trojans. The myth of Danaus, whose origins trace back to Egypt, serves as a foundational legend for Argos. His daughters, the Danaides, were condemned in Tartarus to an endless task of carrying a jug to fill a bottomless bathtub. This myth is linked to unfulfillable endeavors (like Sisyphos), and the name may derive from the PIE root *danu, meaning "river." There is no entirely satisfactory theory regarding their origin. Some scholars connect Danaans with the Denyen, one of the Sea Peoples who attacked Egypt during the reign of Ramesses III (1187-1156 BCE). The same inscription also mentions the Weshesh, who might have been the Achaeans. The Denyen appear to have been inhabitants of the city Adana in Cilicia. Pottery similar to that of Mycenae itself has been discovered in Tarsus of Cilicia, suggesting that some refugees from the Aegean settled there following the collapse of the Mycenaean civilization. These Cilicians seem to have been called Dananiyim, the same term as Danaoi, who attacked Egypt in 1191 BC alongside the Quaouash (or Weshesh), potentially Achaeans. They were also referred to as Danuna in a Hittite inscription, and the same name is mentioned in the Amarna letters. Julius Pokorny reconstructs the name from the PIE root *da:-: "flow, river," *da:-nu: "any moving liquid, drops," *da: navo "people living by the river, Skythian nomadic people (in Rigveda water-demons, fem. Da:nu primordial goddess), in Greek Danaoi, Egyptian Danuna." It is also possible that the name Danaans is pre-Greek. Egyptian inscriptions from Amenophis III (1390-1352 BC) and Thutmosis III (1437 BC) mention a country Danaja with a city Mukana (probably Mycenae).

Scholars such as anthropologist C. Loring Brace, philosophers Jonathan Kaplan and Rasmus Winther, and geneticist Joseph Graves, assert that while biological and genetic variations can indeed correspond roughly to what are commonly termed "continental races," this phenomenon is observable in nearly all geographically distinct populations. Therefore, the cluster structure within genetic data depends on the researcher's initial hypotheses and the specific populations sampled. Should one sample continental groups, continental clusters will form; conversely, different sampling patterns would result in altered clustering. Weiss and Fullerton have demonstrated that if only Icelanders, Mayans, and Maoris were sampled, three distinct clusters would emerge, and all other populations could be characterized as clinally composed of admixtures of Maori, Icelandic, and Mayan genetic material. Kaplan and Winther consequently argue that, viewed this way, both Lewontin and Edwards' positions hold merit. They conclude that while racial groups possess differing allele frequencies, this does not imply that racial classification constitutes a natural taxonomy of the human species, as numerous other genetic patterns exist within human populations that crosscut racial distinctions. Moreover, genomic data does not definitively determine whether one should emphasize subdivisions (i.e., splitters) or a continuum (i.e., lumpers). Under Kaplan and Winther's perspective, racial groupings are objective social constructions (see Mills 1998) that acquire conventional biological reality only to the extent that the categories are chosen and constructed for pragmatic scientific reasons. In prior work, Winther had identified "diversity partitioning" and "clustering analysis" as two distinct methodologies, each with unique questions, assumptions, and protocols, and associated with opposing ontological consequences concerning the metaphysics of race.

The U.S. dollar, unlike the Spanish milled dollar, operates on a decimal system of values. The Coinage Act officially established several monetary units: the mill (one-thousandth of a dollar, ₥), cent (one-hundredth of a dollar, ¢), dime (one-tenth of a dollar), and eagle (ten dollars), each with specified weights and compositions of gold, silver, or copper. In the mid-1800s, a proposal suggested that one hundred dollars be designated a "union," but no union coins were ever minted, with only pattern designs for the $50 half union existing. Currently, only cents are commonly used as subdivisions of the dollar. "Dime" serves solely as the name for the 10¢ coin, while "eagle" and "mill" are largely unknown to the general public. However, mills occasionally appear in tax calculations, and gasoline prices are typically formatted as $X.XX9 per gallon (e.g., $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10). Today, U.S. coins are issued for denominations equal to or less than a dollar, while Federal Reserve notes cover denominations equal to or greater than a dollar. An exception includes gold, silver, and platinum coins, which are legal tender up to $100 but hold significantly higher bullion value. Both one-dollar coins and notes are currently produced, though notes are considerably more common. Historically, "paper money" in denominations under a dollar (known as fractional currency) was sometimes issued, and gold coins circulated up to a $20 value (the "double eagle," discontinued in the 1930s). The Coinage Act of 1792 first used "eagle" for the ten-dollar denomination, and this term was subsequently applied to gold coins. Fractional currency, paper money less than a dollar, was also sometimes derisively called "shinplasters." In 1854, Treasury Secretary James Guthrie proposed creating $100, $50, and $25 gold coins, referred to as a "Union," "Half Union," and "Quarter Union," thereby implying 1 Union equaled $100.

Of the 80 London torch-bearers, Sir Steve Redgrave, who commenced the relay, disclosed to the media that he had received email requests to boycott the event and could "understand their desire to make an issue" of it. Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan declined to carry the torch, while Konnie Huq decided to participate but also spoke out against China. Pro-Tibetan Member of Parliament Norman Baker urged all bearers to reconsider. Amid conflicting pressures, Prime Minister Gordon Brown welcomed the torch outside 10 Downing Street without holding or touching it. During the London relay, the torch was encircled by what the BBC described as "a mobile protective ring." Protests erupted immediately upon Redgrave starting the event, resulting in at least thirty-five arrests. In Ladbroke Grove, a demonstrator attempted to snatch the torch from Konnie Huq during a brief struggle, and in a separate incident, a fire extinguisher was set off near the torch. The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through Chinatown after an unpublicized route change due to security concerns. The torch made an unscheduled move onto a bus along Fleet Street, prompted by security concerns and efforts to evade protesters. To counter the pro-Tibet demonstrators and show support for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, over 2,000 Chinese individuals also gathered along the torch route, demonstrating with signs, banners, and Chinese flags. A large contingent of supporters was concentrated in Trafalgar Square, displaying the Olympic slogan "One World, One Dream."

Several hard rock acts from the 1970s and 1980s maintained remarkably successful recording careers. Bon Jovi, for instance, scored a commercial hit with "It's My Life" from their 2000 double platinum album *Crush*, while AC/DC released the platinum-certified *Stiff Upper Lip* the same year. Aerosmith's *Just Push Play* (2001) became a number two platinum album, showcasing a deeper move into pop with the Top 10 single "Jaded," followed by the 2004 blues cover album *Honkin' on Bobo*, which peaked at number five. Heart's *Red Velvet Car* in 2010 marked their first Top 10 album since the early 90s, making them the first female-fronted hard rock group to achieve Top 10 albums across five decades.

Reunions and tours also took place, including Van Halen (with Hagar in 2004, then Roth in 2007), The Who (postponed until 2006 due to bassist John Entwistle's 2002 death), and Black Sabbath (with Osbourne from 1997–2006, then Dio from 2006–2010). A singular Led Zeppelin performance in 2007 further rekindled interest in earlier periods. Furthermore, hard rock supergroups like Audioslave (featuring ex-members of Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden) and Velvet Revolver (comprising former members of Guns N' Roses, punk band Wasted Youth, and Stone Temple Pilots vocalist Scott Weiland) formed, achieving a degree of success. However, their existence was brief, concluding in 2007 and 2008, respectively.

Guns N' Roses' much-anticipated *Chinese Democracy* finally arrived in 2008, achieving platinum status but falling short of the band's late 1980s and early 1990s commercial heights. More successfully, AC/DC's *Black Ice* (2008) earned double platinum certification. Bon Jovi maintained their success, venturing into country music with "Who Says You Can't Go Home," which topped the Hot Country Singles chart in 2006, and their rock/country album *Lost Highway*, which hit number one in 2007. In 2009, Bon Jovi released *The Circle*, another number one album that signaled a return to their signature hard rock style.

Many contemporary specialty matches have been introduced, each featuring unique winning conditions. The ladder match is the most common among these. In a basic ladder match, wrestlers or teams must climb a ladder to retrieve a prize suspended above the ring. The core strategy for winning involves incapacitating opponents long enough for one wrestler to ascend the ladder and secure the prize for their side. Consequently, the ladder frequently serves as a weapon. Prizes can include – but are not limited to – a championship belt (the traditional reward), a contract granting a future title opportunity, or any document significant to the participants, such as one for a cash prize.

Another prevalent specialty match is the battle royal. In this format, all wrestlers enter the ring simultaneously, often leading to 20-30 competitors being present at once. Upon the match's commencement, the objective is simply to eliminate opponents by throwing them over the top rope, ensuring both their feet touch the floor outside the ring. The last wrestler remaining in the ring is declared the winner. A notable variant is WWE's Royal Rumble, where two wrestlers begin the match, and additional competitors enter at 90-second intervals (previously 2 minutes) until 30-40 wrestlers have participated. All other rules for elimination remain the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.

By March 2011, OS X's presence in the North American market had expanded to slightly exceeding 14%. The significance of the Mac's market share and user base, and for whom it matters, remains a contentious subject. Industry observers frequently pointed to the Mac's comparatively small market share as a sign of Apple's impending collapse, particularly during the early to mid-1990s when the company's prospects appeared bleak. Conversely, some argue that evaluating the Mac's prosperity based on market share is misguided. Apple has positioned the Mac as a premium personal computer, rendering direct comparisons with more affordable PCs potentially inaccurate. Due to the rapid expansion of the overall personal computer market, the Mac's increasing sales figures are effectively overshadowed by the industry's broader sales growth. Consequently, Apple's modest market share creates the false impression that Mac usage has declined over the past decade, when in reality, the opposite is true. The surge in iPhone and iPad sales meant that the Macintosh's contribution to Apple's profits decreased in 2010, falling to 24% from 46% two years earlier. Others seek to diminish the importance of market share, noting its rare mention in other industries. Regardless of the Mac's market share, Apple has maintained profitability since Steve Jobs' return and the subsequent corporate restructuring. Notably, a report from the first quarter of 2008 indicated Apple held a 14% market share in the US personal computer market, encompassing 66% of all computers priced above $1,000. Market analysis suggests that Apple attracts a customer demographic with higher incomes than the general personal computer market.

The 1998 season began somberly with the passing of legendary broadcaster Harry Caray. Following Sandberg's retirement and Dunston's trade, the Cubs had voids to fill, and the acquisition of Henry Rodríguez, affectionately known as "H-Rod," to bat cleanup offered protection for Sammy Sosa in the lineup; Rodriguez blasted 31 home runs in his inaugural season in Chicago. Kevin Tapani topped the team with a career-high 19 wins, Rod Beck anchored a formidable bullpen, and Mark Grace delivered one of his finest seasons. The Cubs were inundated with media attention in 1998, with Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood being the team's two biggest draws. Wood's standout performance was a one-hitter against the Houston Astros, a game where he equaled the major league record of 20 strikeouts over nine innings. His blistering strikeout totals earned Wood the moniker "Kid K" and ultimately secured him the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs that month, and his home run chase with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire elevated the pair to international superstardom within weeks. McGwire concluded the season with a new major league record of 70 home runs, but Sosa's .308 average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award. After a nail-biting Wild Card pursuit against the San Francisco Giants, Chicago and San Francisco finished the regular season tied, necessitating a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field where third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the decisive home run. This victory propelled the Cubs into the postseason once more, ending the regular season with a 90–73 record. Regrettably, the offense went cold in October, as manager Jim Riggleman's squad batted .183 and managed only four runs, leading to a sweep by Atlanta. On a positive note, the home run race involving Sosa, McGwire, and Ken Griffey, Jr. helped professional baseball attract a new generation of fans and brought back some who had been disillusioned by the 1994 strike. The Cubs retained many players who had career-best years in '98, but after a strong start in 1999, they collapsed again (beginning with a mid-June sweep by the cross-town White Sox) and finished at the bottom of their division for the subsequent two seasons.

The university's physical infrastructure has expanded significantly since the construction of its initial buildings. Over time, 29 residence halls have been erected to house students, each featuring its own chapel. Numerous academic buildings were added, along with a network of libraries, the most notable being the Theodore Hesburgh Library, established in 1963 and currently holding nearly 4 million books. Since 2004, several structures have been incorporated, including the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center, the Guglielmino Complex, and the Jordan Hall of Science. Additionally, construction began on Duncan Hall, a new men's residence, on March 8, 2007, which started accepting residents for the Fall 2008 semester. Ryan Hall was finished and commenced housing undergraduate women in the fall of 2009. Recent completions also include Stinson-Remick Hall, a new engineering building; Geddes Hall, a new facility combining the Center for Social Concerns and the Institute for Church Life; and an expansion to the law school. The new hockey arena also opened in the fall of 2011. In March 2013, the Stayer Center for Executive Education, which houses the Mendoza College of Business Executive Education Department, opened just south of the Mendoza College of Business building. Due to its rich athletic heritage, the university also features many buildings dedicated to sports. The most famous is Notre Dame Stadium, home to the Fighting Irish football team, which has been renovated multiple times and now seats over 80,000 people. Other prominent venues include the Edmund P. Joyce Center, with indoor basketball and volleyball courts, and the Compton Family Ice Arena, a two-rink facility for hockey. Furthermore, there are numerous outdoor fields, such as Frank Eck Stadium for baseball.

American comic books have incorporated this character archetype into their narratives, exemplified by Marvel Comics' mutant-villain, the Silver Samurai. His design faithfully retains the samurai appearance; the antagonist is described as "Clad in traditional gleaming samurai armor and wielding an energy charged katana" (Buxton, 2013). Beyond over 350 comic book appearances, the Silver Samurai is also a playable character in various video games, including Marvel Vs. Capcom 1 and 2. In 2013, James Mangold's film The Wolverine featured this samurai antagonist. A decade prior to The Wolverine's debut, another film significantly introduced samurai to American cinema: The Last Samurai, a 2003 movie starring Tom Cruise, drew inspiration from the samurai way of life. In the film, Cruise's character becomes profoundly immersed in samurai culture. The character, "Nathan Algren, is a fictional contrivance to make nineteenth-century Japanese history less foreign to American viewers" (Ravina, 2010). After being captured by a group of samurai rebels, he develops empathy for their cause. Set during the Meiji Period, Tom Cruise portrays US Army Captain Nathan Algren, who travels to Japan to train an inexperienced army to combat samurai rebel groups. Influenced by his environment, Algren ultimately joins the samurai clan in an effort to rescue a captured samurai leader. By the film's conclusion, "he has clearly taken on many of the samurai traits, such as zen-like mastery of the sword, and a budding understanding of spirituality" (Manion, 2006).

A true predator is typically defined as an organism that kills and consumes another living thing. While other predator types inflict harm on their prey, this specific form results in death. Predators employ various hunting strategies, either actively pursuing their prey, known as pursuit predation, or waiting for it to come within range, characteristic of ambush predators. Certain predators, like jaguars or humans, dispatch large prey and then dismember or chew it before consumption; conversely, others, such as bottlenose dolphins, snakes, ducks, or storks, ingest their (often much smaller) prey whole. Animals like domestic cats and dogs, capable of killing both large and small prey relative to their size, adapt their eating methods: they might swallow a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some forms of predation involve venom that incapacitates the prey before ingestion; this can either kill the prey, as seen with box jellyfish, or disable it, a tactic used by cone shells. For certain predators, like rattlesnakes and some spiders, venom also initiates the digestion process of the prey even before the predator starts feeding. Alternatively, the prey organism might perish within the predator's mouth or digestive tract. Baleen whales, for instance, consume millions of microscopic plankton, which are processed long after being swallowed. Seed predation and egg predation also qualify as true predation, given that seeds and eggs are considered potential organisms. Not all predators in this category consume their prey entirely; some cannot digest bones, while others can. Even when only a portion of an organism is eaten, such as in grazing (see below), the predator consistently causes its direct demise.

In 680, Ibn al-Zubayr departed Medina for Mecca. Upon learning of Husayn's defiance against Yazid I, the Kufans invited Husayn to assume leadership, pledging their allegiance. Al-Husayn dispatched his cousin, Muslim bin Agail, to ascertain the depth of their support. Receiving this intelligence, Yazid I instructed Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad, the governor of Basra, to thwart any Kufan mobilization for Al-Husayn. Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad successfully dispersed the assembly around Muslim bin Agail and subsequently apprehended him. Aware of Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad's directive to obstruct Husayn's establishment of support in Kufa, Muslim bin Agail sought to send a message urging Husayn not to proceed to Kufa. His plea was rejected, and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad executed Muslim bin Agail. While Ibn al-Zubayr remained in Mecca until his demise, Husayn, ignorant of the absence of support, proceeded towards Kufa with his family. Husayn and his kin were intercepted by Yazid I's forces, commanded by Amru bin Saad, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim, who engaged Al-Husayn and his male relatives until their deaths. Husayn's caravan comprised 200 individuals, many of whom were women, including his sisters, wives, daughters, and their offspring. The women and children from Husayn's company were captured as prisoners of war and marched to Damascus for presentation to Yazid I. They remained incarcerated until public sentiment shifted against Yazid I as news of Husayn's demise and his family's capture disseminated. Subsequently, they were granted safe passage back to Medina. The only adult male survivor from the caravan was Ali ibn Husayn, who was too debilitated by fever to participate in the fighting during the attack.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary representatives Luis G. Cuevas, Bernardo Couto, and Miguel Atristain, brought an end to the conflict, affirming the U.S.'s undisputed control of Texas and establishing the Rio Grande as the U.S.–Mexican border. Upon receiving news of the peace negotiations, calls for renewed military action emerged among the state's populace. However, on February 8, 1848, after Chihuahua's Mexican officials learned General Price was returning to Mexico from Santa Fe with a substantial force, including infantry, cavalry, and light artillery, Ángel Trías dispatched a message to Sacramento Pass requesting the area's succession, believing the war had ended. General Price misconstrued this request as a deceptive tactic by Mexican forces and pressed on towards the state capital. On March 16, 1848, Price initiated talks with Ángel Trías, only for the Mexican leader to issue an ultimatum in response. American and Mexican forces subsequently clashed near Santa Cruz de los Rosales on March 16, 1848. The Battle of Santa Cruz de los Rosales marked the final engagement of the Mexican–American War, notably taking place after the peace treaty's signing. American forces retained control over the state capital for three months following the peace treaty's confirmation. This American presence effectively postponed the state's potential secession, a topic debated since late 1847, with the region remaining under United States occupation until May 22, 1848.

In December 2015, West launched the song "Facts." He subsequently declared on Twitter in January 2016 that his album, then titled SWISH, would be released on February 11, following the debut of "Real Friends" and a preview of "No More Parties in L.A." featuring Kendrick Lamar. This period also saw the resurgence of the GOOD Fridays initiative, where West would drop new singles weekly. On January 26, 2016, West disclosed the album's renaming from SWISH to Waves and simultaneously announced the premiere of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line at Madison Square Garden. Early in 2016, a few weeks before the album's launch, West became entangled in a brief Twitter dispute with rapper Wiz Khalifa, which eventually drew in their shared ex-partner, Amber Rose. Rose objected to West's reference to her and Khalifa's child, and the dispute escalated with her making allegations about her past sexual relationship with West, garnering considerable media attention. By February 2, 2016, West and Khalifa had settled their differences. Days before the album's scheduled release, West altered the title once more, this time to The Life of Pablo. On February 11, West unveiled the album at Madison Square Garden during the presentation of his Yeezy Season 3 collection. Following this preview, West stated that he would adjust the track list again before its public availability and postponed the release further to complete the recording of the track "Waves," at the request of co-writer Chance the Rapper. The album was then released exclusively on Tidal on February 14, 2016, after his performance on SNL.

Conversely, the Kingdom's ineffective royal justice system instigated the social upheaval known as the Guerras Irmandiñas ('Wars of the brotherhoods'). During this conflict, alliances of peasants and burghers, backed by various knights and noblemen, and operating under the distant king's legal protection, demolished many castles throughout the Kingdom and temporarily drove the nobility into Portugal and Castile. Soon after, in the late 15th century, during the dynastic struggle between Isabella I of Castile and Joanna La Beltraneja, a segment of the Galician aristocracy sided with Joanna. Following Isabella's triumph, she initiated administrative and political reforms, which the chronicler Jeronimo Zurita termed "doma del Reino de Galicia," explaining, 'It was then when the taming of Galicia began, because not just the local lords and knights, but all the people of that nation were the ones against the others very bold and warlike.' These reforms, while establishing a local government and court (the Real Audiencia del Reino de Galicia) and bringing the nobility to heel, also subjected most Galician monasteries and institutions to Castilian control, a move widely criticized as centralizing. Concurrently, the monarchs began convening the Xunta or Cortes of the Kingdom of Galicia, an assembly comprising deputies or representatives from the Kingdom's cities, to solicit monetary and military contributions. This assembly quickly evolved into the Kingdom's voice and legal representation, becoming the custodian of its will and legislation.

Terry Eastland, author of *Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice*, asserts that most rationales for affirmative action fall into two categories: rectifying past discrimination and fostering diversity. Eastland contends that affirmative action's originators did not foresee its benefits accruing to those who did not need them, primarily middle-class minorities. She further argues that these policies carry a stigma, which can induce feelings of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities. Eastland views affirmative action as a significant gamble that only occasionally yields positive returns, suggesting that without it, individuals would compete more freely. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell, in his book *Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study*, identified what he describes as negative consequences of affirmative action. Sowell writes that these policies incentivize non-preferred groups to identify themselves as members of preferred groups (i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action) to exploit group preference policies; that they tend to primarily benefit the most privileged within the preferred group (e.g., upper and middle-class Black individuals), often at the detriment of the least fortunate among non-preferred groups (e.g., poor White or Asian individuals); that they diminish the motivation for both preferred and non-preferred groups to perform optimally—the former because it's unnecessary and the latter because it can prove futile—thereby leading to net losses for society as a whole; and that they foster animosity toward preferred groups.

The Royal Assent ritual unfolds in the Senate, as the monarch is historically precluded from the House of Commons. On the day of the proceedings, the Speaker of the Senate will inform the chamber of a message from the governor general's secretary, specifying the arrival time of the viceroy or a designated deputy. Following this, the Senate is prohibited from adjourning until the ceremony has concluded. The speaker then moves to a seat next to the throne, the Mace Bearer stands close by, mace in hand, and the governor general enters to occupy the speaker's chair. The Usher of the Black Rod is subsequently instructed by the speaker to summon the Members of Parliament, who then follow Black Rod back to the Senate, with the Sergeant-at-Arms carrying the mace of the House of Commons. Within the Senate, those from the commons remain behind the bar, while Black Rod positions himself or herself beside the governor general, who then nods to grant Royal Assent to the bills presented (excluding appropriations bills). Once this list of bills is finalized, the Clerk of the Senate declares: "in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] doth assent to these bills." Should any appropriation bills require Royal Assent, the Speaker of the House of Commons will recite their titles, and the Senate clerk repeats them to the governor general, who nods to convey Royal Assent. When all these bills have received assent, the Clerk of the Senate recites "in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] thanks her loyal subjects, accepts their benevolence and assents to these bills. The governor general or their deputy then departs from parliament.

Libya experienced economic difficulties in the early to mid-1980s, with annual oil revenues plummeting from $21 billion to $5.4 billion between 1982 and 1986. Construction began in 1983 on the Great Man-Made River, "Gaddafi's Pet Project," an ambitious irrigation scheme intended for completion by the decade's end, yet it was still unfinished in the early 2000s. Concurrently, military expenditures rose as other administrative budgets faced cutbacks. Libya, a long-term supporter of Chad's FROLINAT militia, re-invaded the country in December 1980 at the Frolinat-dominated GUNT government's request to intervene in the civil war, followed by Gaddafi's proposal for a political merger in January 1981. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected this proposal, demanding a Libyan withdrawal, which occurred in November 1981. However, the civil war reignited, prompting Libya to redeploy troops, leading to clashes with French forces who were backing southern Chadian factions. Libya's foreign interference policies had alienated many African nations; by 1980, nine African states had severed diplomatic ties, and in 1982, the OAU canceled its Tripoli conference to block Gaddafi from assuming chairmanship. Seeking political unity with Morocco, Gaddafi and Moroccan monarch Hassan II signed the Oujda Treaty in August 1984, establishing the Arab-African Union—a surprising move given the profound political differences and historical animosity between their governments. Nevertheless, relations remained tense, largely owing to Morocco's amicable ties with the U.S. and Israel; Hassan ultimately dissolved the union in August 1986. Domestically, Gaddafi faced ongoing threats; in May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia residence was targeted in an unsuccessful attack by a combined NFSL–Muslim Brotherhood militia, resulting in the arrest of 5,000 dissidents.

LaserDisc technology facilitated sound storage in either analog or digital formats, encompassing various surround sound options. NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks alongside two uncompressed PCM digital audio tracks, characterized by EFM, CIRC, 16-bit, and a 44.056 kHz sample rate. Conversely, PAL discs supported a single pair of audio tracks, which could be either analog or digital, with the digital tracks matching CD specifications at 16-bit 44.1 kHz. In the UK, "LaserVision" specifically referred to discs featuring analog sound, while "LaserDisc" was reserved for those with digital audio. Digital sound signals in both formats utilized EFM encoding, consistent with CDs. Dolby Digital (AC-3) and DTS, now common on DVD releases, made their initial appearance on LaserDisc. Notably, the Japanese LaserDisc release of *Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace* (1999) was among the first home video titles to include 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround. Unlike DVDs, which transmit Dolby Digital audio digitally, LaserDiscs stored it in a frequency-modulated form within a track typically used for analog audio. Extracting Dolby Digital from a LaserDisc required a player equipped with a special "AC-3 RF" output, an external demodulator, and an AC-3 decoder. The demodulator's role was to convert the disc's 2.88 MHz modulated AC-3 information into a 384 kbit/s signal that the decoder could process. DTS audio, when available on a disc, superseded the digital audio tracks, and its playback only required an S/PDIF compliant digital connection to a DTS decoder.

Through his diagrams illustrating a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman was able to construct a model for all of physics, based on these particles' spins and the coupling range of the fundamental forces. He proposed the parton model to explain the strong interactions observed in nucleon scattering. This parton model emerged as a counterpart to the quark model developed by his Caltech colleague, Murray Gell-Mann. The connection between the two models was ambiguous; Gell-Mann even disparagingly referred to Feynman's partons as "put-ons." In the mid-1960s, physicists generally considered quarks to be conceptual accounting devices for symmetry numbers rather than actual particles, particularly because the statistics of the Omega-minus particle, if understood as three identical strange quarks bound together, seemed to contradict the idea of real quarks. However, the deep inelastic scattering experiments at the Stanford linear accelerator in the late 1960s, mirroring Ernest Rutherford's 1911 experiment with alpha particles on gold nuclei, demonstrated that nucleons (protons and neutrons) contained point-like constituents that scattered electrons. While it was logical to equate these with quarks, Feynman's parton model sought to interpret the experimental findings without introducing additional theoretical assumptions. For example, the data indicated that approximately 45% of the energy momentum within the nucleon was carried by electrically-neutral particles. These neutral particles are now understood to be gluons, which transmit the forces between quarks and also carry the three-valued color quantum number that resolved the Omega-minus paradox. Feynman never disputed the quark model; for instance, upon the discovery of the fifth quark in 1977, he promptly informed his students that this implied the existence of a sixth quark, which was subsequently found in the decade following his death.

Late in 1203, John sought to relieve Château Gaillard, a fortress under Philip's siege yet crucial for defending Normandy's eastern border. He launched a coordinated land and naval assault, an approach most contemporary historians deem imaginatively conceived but too intricate for the era's military capabilities to execute effectively. Philip's forces thwarted John's relief efforts, prompting John to withdraw to Brittany, hoping to divert Philip from eastern Normandy. While John successfully ravaged a large part of Brittany, this failed to redirect Philip's primary offensive in eastern Normandy. Historians hold differing views on John's military competence during this campaign, though most recent scholars describe his performance as adequate, if unremarkable. John's position swiftly worsened. For years, Philip and his predecessors had extensively cultivated Normandy's eastern frontier, while Angevin authority in the south had been eroded by Richard's earlier ceding of vital castles. Furthermore, his reliance on routier mercenaries in central areas quickly dissipated his remaining local support, paving the way for a rapid collapse of Angevin rule. In December, John retreated across the Channel, issuing directives for a new defensive line to be established west of Château Gaillard. Château Gaillard fell in March 1204. John's mother, Eleanor, passed away the subsequent month. This loss was not only a personal tragedy for John but also jeopardized the extensive Angevin alliances throughout southern France. Philip bypassed the new defensive line, moving south and then striking northward into the Duchy's core, encountering minimal opposition. By August, Philip had secured Normandy and pushed further south to occupy Anjou and Poitou. The Duchy of Aquitaine became John's sole remaining continental possession.

However, in 2013, a study on Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA conducted by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached different conclusions, again supporting the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. Testing encompassed the full 16,600 DNA units composing mitochondrial DNA in all subjects (unlike the 2006 Behar study which had only tested 1,000 units). This research found that the four main female Ashkenazi founders had descent lines established in Europe between 10,000 and 20,000 years ago, while most of the remaining minor founders also exhibited deep European ancestry. The study posited that the great majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages were not introduced from the Near East (i.e., they were non-Israelite), nor were they recruited from the Caucasus (i.e., they were non-Khazar), but rather were assimilated within Europe, primarily tracing back to Italian and Old French origins. Richards summarized the findings regarding the female line as such: "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom that flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry originates from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent from the Near East, with the source of the remainder being undetermined. According to the study, these findings "point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities."

The 1912 Salon d'Automne featured an architectural installation, swiftly named Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), credited to Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare, alongside several collaborators. In their text Du "Cubisme", penned while the "Maison Cubiste" was being assembled, Metzinger and Gleizes articulated art's inherent autonomy, emphasizing that aesthetic choices should not dictate its essence. They considered decorative endeavors the "antithesis of the picture." A "true picture," as Metzinger and Gleizes stated, "carries its own justification. It is transferable from a church to a drawing-room, or from a museum to a study. Fundamentally self-sufficient and complete, it isn't meant to instantly gratify the mind; instead, it ought to guide it gradually toward the imagined depths where a unifying clarity dwells. It does not align with a particular setting; rather, it resonates with existence itself, with the cosmos: it functions as an organism..." Christopher Green observes that "Mare's arrangements were deemed suitable backdrops for Cubist creations, as they preserved the autonomy of paintings and sculptures, generating a dynamic interplay of contrasts. This explains the participation of Gleizes and Metzinger themselves, alongside Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (with Raymond Duchamp-Villon specifically designing the facade), and Mare's long-time associates Léger and Roger La Fresnaye." The Maison Cubiste presented a complete, furnished dwelling, featuring a staircase, wrought iron banisters, a living room—known as the Salon Bourgeois, which showcased paintings by Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger (including "Woman with a Fan"), Gleizes, Laurencin, and Léger—and a bedroom. It embodied L'art décoratif, serving as a setting where Cubist artworks could be admired amidst the contemporary, bourgeois lifestyle. Visitors to the Salon d'Automne entered via a full-scale, 10-by-3-meter plaster rendition of the ground-floor facade, a design by Duchamp-Villon. This architectural piece later traveled to the 1913 Armory Show, appearing in New York, Chicago, and Boston. In the New York exhibition catalogue, it was itemized as Raymond Duchamp-Villon, number 609, and titled "Facade architectural, plaster" (Façade architecturale).

Modern rock musicians incorporate mandolins, frequently opting for single-stringed electric models over the traditional double-stringed acoustic versions. Tim Brennan from the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys serves as one such example. Beyond the standard electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band integrates various instruments linked to traditional Celtic music, such as the mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes. The band articulates that these instruments enhance the raw, "growling" sound they prefer. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was largely propelled by simple mandolin licks performed by guitarist Peter Buck, who also featured the mandolin in approximately a dozen other tracks. This single reached its peak at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, also topping the rock and alternative charts. Luther Dickinson, known for his work with North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes, has utilized the mandolin extensively, particularly on The Black Crowes' track "Locust Street." The Armenian American rock ensemble System of A Down heavily features the mandolin on their 2005 double album, Mezmerize/Hypnotize. Pop punk group Green Day has incorporated a mandolin on multiple occasions, especially on their 2000 album, Warning. Boyd Tinsley, the violinist for the Dave Matthews Band, has incorporated an electric mandolin into his setup since 2005. Both frontman Colin Meloy and guitarist Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly employ the mandolin within the band's musical arrangements. Nancy Wilson, Heart's rhythm guitarist, plays a mandolin in their song "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen, and also in Heart's rendition of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore."
