In 1951, President Truman, reflecting a widespread public desire for an Eisenhower presidency, once more urged him to seek the office as a Democrat. It was then that Eisenhower articulated his disagreements with the Democratic party, declaring himself and his family to be Republicans. A Republican "Draft Eisenhower" initiative eventually convinced him to announce his candidacy for the 1952 presidential election, primarily to counteract the non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. This effort proved challenging; Eisenhower had to be assured that political circumstances truly compelled him to offer himself, and that a clear mandate from the populace for him to lead existed. Henry Cabot Lodge, who managed his campaign, and other supporters successfully persuaded him, prompting his resignation from his NATO command in June 1952 to campaign full-time. Eisenhower secured the nomination by defeating Taft, thanks to critical delegate votes from Texas. Eisenhower's campaign became known for its simple yet effective slogan, "I Like Ike." Crucial to his triumph was Eisenhower's public opposition to Roosevelt's Yalta policy and Truman's actions in Korea and China—matters in which he had previously played a role. His victory over Taft for the nomination necessitated appeasing the Republican Party's right-wing Old Guard; his selection of Richard M. Nixon as his running mate was partly designed to achieve this. Nixon also provided a staunch anti-communist voice and youthful energy to offset Ike's seniority.

In 2006, Morgan Stanley acquired 20 acres (8.1 ha) immediately north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino, intending to develop a new casino resort valued at over $2 billion. Revel Entertainment Group was designated as the project's developer for what would become Revel Casino. The Revel project encountered a series of difficulties, with its most significant challenge emerging in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, holding a 90% ownership stake in Revel Entertainment Group, decided to cease funding for ongoing construction and offered its interest in Revel for sale. Earlier in 2010, the New Jersey state legislature approved a bill providing tax incentives to attract fresh investors and complete the development, yet a March 2010 poll by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind revealed that three out of five voters (60%) opposed the legislation, and two-thirds of those objectors "strongly" opposed it. Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie extended $261 million in state tax credits to Revel to support the casino once it commenced operations. By March 2011, Revel had completed all exterior construction and progressed with interior work, having finally secured the requisite funding to finish the build. It commenced a soft opening in April 2012, achieving full operation by May 2012. Just ten months later, in February 2013, following substantial financial losses and a drastic revaluation of the resort's worth from $2.4 billion to $450 million, Revel sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Despite restructuring, it failed to sustain operations and re-entered bankruptcy on June 19, 2014. The property was put up for sale, but due to a lack of acceptable bids, the resort ceased operations on September 2, 2014.

A crucial component of identity development is self-esteem, which refers to an individual's perceptions and emotions regarding their self-concept and sense of identity. Most theories suggest a fundamental drive across all age groups and genders to preserve, safeguard, and improve one's self-esteem. Despite common misconceptions, there is no strong empirical evidence indicating a significant decline in self-esteem during adolescence. While "barometric self-esteem" experiences rapid changes, leading to considerable distress and anxiety, an individual's fundamental self-esteem remains remarkably consistent throughout the adolescent years. The reliability of general self-esteem measures has been debated, with many proposing that more specialized assessments could offer greater insights into the adolescent journey. Girls typically experience elevated self-esteem when they are involved in supportive friendships, viewing the primary role of these relationships as providing social and moral backing. Conversely, girls suffer from diminished self-esteem when they fail to gain their friends' approval or cannot find companions for shared activities and interests. Boys, however, are more concerned with asserting their autonomy and defining their position relative to authority figures. Consequently, their self-esteem is more likely to be boosted by their ability to successfully sway their peers; conversely, a lack of romantic proficiency, such as the inability to secure or sustain the affection of a partner (of any sexual orientation), is a primary cause of low self-esteem in adolescent boys. Following the dissolution of a romantic relationship, both men and women often experience reduced self-esteem, which can trigger additional symptoms. Depression and feelings of hopelessness are just two such manifestations, with women being twice as prone to depression and men three to four times more likely to engage in suicide (Mearns, 1991; Ustun & Sartorius, 1995).

The Nintendo Entertainment System's full North American launch involved a phased release over several years, introducing four distinct bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set, and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, priced at US$199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., an NES Zapper light gun, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set was available for US$89.99 without a game, or US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros." In 1988, the Action Set retailed for US$149.99, comprising the Control Deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak featuring both Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. The Power Set, launched in 1989, offered the console, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing Super Mario Bros., Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. A Sports Set bundle followed in 1990, providing the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four game controllers, and a dual Game Pak with Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Subsequently, two additional bundle packages utilizing the original model NES console were released. The 1992 Challenge Set, priced at US$89.99, came with the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 Game Pak. The Basic Set, initially released in 1987, was re-packaged at US$89.99, containing only the console and two controllers, and no longer included a game cartridge. Instead, it featured the Official Nintendo Player's Guide, a book detailing every NES game released up to that point.

The Liberal party then experienced a period of internal strife, as former Treasurer John Howard and former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock vied for leadership. This occurred against the backdrop of Australia's early 1990s recession, which saw unemployment peak at 11.4% in 1992. In November 1991, under Dr. John Hewson's leadership, the opposition unveiled its comprehensive 650-page "Fightback!" policy document. This package comprised a radical suite of "dry" economic liberal reforms, including the implementation of a Goods and Services Tax (GST), modifications to Medicare such as ending bulk billing for those without concessions, a nine-month cap on unemployment benefits, significant industrial relations overhauls like the abolition of awards, a $13 billion personal income tax reduction targeting middle and upper earners, $10 billion in government expenditure cuts, the elimination of state payroll taxes, and the privatization of numerous state-owned entities. These proposals signaled a distinct shift from the Keynesian economic conservatism previously practiced by Liberal/National Coalition governments. The 15 percent GST formed the core of the policy. Throughout 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating launched a vigorous campaign against the "Fightback" agenda, particularly assailing the GST as an assault on the working class, arguing it would reallocate the tax burden from direct taxation of the affluent to a broad-based consumption tax. Intense pressure from advocacy groups and public sentiment ultimately compelled Hewson to exclude food from the proposed GST, leading to intricate questions about which food items would qualify for exemption. Hewson's struggles to articulate this to the public were famously highlighted in the "birthday cake interview," widely regarded as a pivotal moment in the election race. Keating subsequently secured a historic fifth consecutive term for Labor in the 1993 election. While a number of these policy concepts were later enacted into law in various forms—to a minor degree during the Keating Labor administration and more substantially during the Howard Liberal government (most notably the GST)—unemployment benefits and bulk billing were later re-evaluated for a period by the Abbott Liberal government.

In 356, Constantius ordered Liberius into exile, granting him three days to comply with banishment to Beroea, in Thrace. He also sent expensive gifts, which Liberius refused, contingent on his acceptance of the Arian position. Specifically, Constantius sent five hundred pieces of gold "to cover his expenses," but Liberius declined, suggesting they be given to his flatterers. He similarly rejected a gift from the empress, instructing her messenger to believe in Christ and cease persecuting the Church of God. Attempts to leave the presents within the Church were met with Liberius throwing them out.

Constantius subsequently had Liberius brought under strict guard to Milan, where, in a conference recorded by Theodoret, Liberius boldly declared to Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted at Sardica, and his enemies proven calumniators and impostors. He further argued it was unjust to condemn someone without legal conviction of a crime. The emperor was silenced on every point but, growing more impatient, reissued the order for Liberius's banishment, which Liberius then undertook.

Two years later, Constantius visited Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The city's ladies petitioned him for Liberius's restoration. Constantius assented, provided Liberius complied with the bishops then at court. Liberius subsequently subscribed to the condemnation of Athanasius and a confession or creed framed by the Arians at Sirmium. However, as Theodoret testifies (Hist. lib. ii. c. 17.), upon regaining his see, he immediately declared his adherence to the Nicene Creed. Both the Emperor and his court bishops were clear on what they wanted people to believe, while Athanasius remained steadfast in the orthodox creed. Constantius, an avowed Arian, had become sole ruler in 350 after the death of his brother, Constans.

Montana Territory was established on April 26, 1864, with the passage of the U.S. Organic Act. Prior to its official territorial status, schools began to emerge as families settled the region. The initial schools were subscription-based, often operating from the teacher's residence. The earliest documented formal school opened in 1862 at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley, serving Indian children and the offspring of Fort Owen staff. Its first term commenced in early winter and concluded on February 28, with Mr. Robinson as the instructor. Thomas Dimsdale initiated another early subscription school in Virginia City in 1863, where students were charged $1.75 weekly. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly convened for the first time in 1864. This inaugural legislature empowered counties to collect taxes for schools, laying the groundwork for public education. Madison County was the first to utilize these new tax provisions, establishing the first public school in Virginia City in 1866. Although slated to open in January 1866, severe weather delayed its start until March. The school year extended through the summer, concluding on August 17. Sarah Raymond, a 25-year-old who arrived in Virginia City by wagon train in 1865, was among its first teachers. To qualify, Raymond passed an exam at home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust for her teaching certificate. Assisted by Mrs. Farley, she was responsible for instructing 50 to 60 of the 81 enrolled students daily. Sarah Raymond earned $125 monthly, while Mrs. Farley received $75. No textbooks were used; instead, students relied on a variety of books brought by various emigrants. Sarah left teaching the following year but later became the Madison County superintendent of schools.

Following a vote of thanks from the Commons on June 20, 1794, for his contributions to the Hastings Trial, Burke promptly relinquished his parliamentary seat, which was subsequently filled by his son, Richard. However, a profound personal tragedy struck Burke in August 1794 with the death of Richard, his son, for whom he held deep affection. Burke perceived great potential in Richard, though this promise was not evident to others and, arguably, seemed to be unfounded (a perception perhaps influenced by Richard's successful early involvement in the campaign for Catholic emancipation). King George III, having been impressed by Burke's stance on the French Revolution, intended to bestow upon him the title of Earl of Beaconsfield. Yet, his son's passing rendered such an honour and its associated allure meaningless to Burke, leading him to accept only a pension of £2,500. Even this relatively modest recompense drew criticism from the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale. Burke responded to their attacks in his *Letter to a Noble Lord* (1796), famously stating: "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He contended that his reward was merited, while the Duke of Bedford's wealth stemmed solely from inheritance, his forebear being the initial recipient of a pension. Burke sharply contrasted them: "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth". Burke further alluded to the potential consequences for individuals if their revolutionary ideologies were enacted, and also incorporated a detailed description of the British

The country almost immediately descended into a civil war, characterized by various factions, often defined by clan affiliations, clashing against each other. During this period, more than 500,000 residents became displaced, fleeing due to persecution, escalating poverty, or in pursuit of improved economic prospects in Western nations or other former Soviet states. Emomali Rahmon assumed power in 1992, securing a victory over former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the votes. These elections occurred soon after the conclusion of the war, at which point Tajikistan lay in complete ruin. The death toll was estimated to exceed 100,000, and approximately 1.2 million people were displaced as refugees both within and outside the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was brokered between Rahmon and opposition parties, facilitated by Gerd D. Merrem, the Special Representative to the Secretary General, a development widely lauded as an effective United Nations peace-keeping initiative. The agreement stipulated that 30% of ministerial posts would be allocated to the opposition. Elections took place in 1999, though they faced criticism from opposition groups and international observers for being unjust, resulting in Rahmon's re-election with 98% of the vote. Rahmon again won the 2006 elections with 79% of the vote, commencing his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election, and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, despite observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States declaring the elections lawful and transparent. Rahmon's government garnered further censure from the OSCE in October 2010 concerning its censorship and suppression of the media. Various theories have been proposed to account for Yale's prominent role in national elections since the Vietnam War concluded. Many sources highlight a persistent spirit of campus activism at Yale since the 1960s, along with the significant intellectual impact of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on numerous prospective candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes this trend to the university's dedication to fostering "a laboratory for future leaders," a core institutional objective established under Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and current president of Duke University, remarked on the "very significant attention" paid to community orientation in admissions and Yale's "very strong tradition of volunteerism." Yale historian Gaddis Smith points to a 20th-century "ethos of organized activity" at the university, which saw John Kerry lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman manage the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia suggests a history rooted in networking and elitism, explaining it as "a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN indicates that George W. Bush profited from preferential admissions given his status as the "son and grandson of alumni" and a "member of a politically influential family." New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly correspondent James Fallows credit a strong culture of community and cooperation among students, faculty, and administration, which diminishes self-interest and strengthens dedication to others.

The final significant architectural work took place during King George V's reign, when in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redeveloped Blore's 1850 East Front to partially emulate Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This newly refaced main façade, constructed from Portland stone, was conceived as a setting for the Victoria Memorial, a large statue of Queen Victoria located outside the principal gates. George V, who succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious temperament than his father, leading to a greater emphasis on official entertaining and royal duties rather than lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – which was the first jazz performance for a head of state – Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932). This earned the palace a 2009 nomination for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, acknowledging it as one of the venues that contributed most significantly to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife, Queen Mary, was an arts connoisseur, keenly interested in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, which she both restored and expanded. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the 1810 pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, which she placed in the ground-floor Bow Room, a vast, low chamber at the heart of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This 69-foot (21-meter) long room, previously known as the South Drawing Room, boasts a ceiling specially designed by Nash, featuring coffers with enormous gilt console brackets.

Luís Figo's departure, as the club's vice-captain, largely eclipsed the less-noticed exits of Núñez and van Gaal among fans. Figo had become a cult hero, regarded by Catalans as one of their own. However, Barcelona supporters were devastated by Figo's move to arch-rivals Real Madrid, leading to an extremely hostile reception during his subsequent appearances at the Camp Nou. His initial return saw a piglet's head and a full whiskey bottle hurled at him from the stands. The subsequent three years marked a period of club decline, characterized by a revolving door of managers. Llorenç Serra Ferrer succeeded van Gaal, and despite significant player investment in summer 2000, he oversaw a disappointing league season and an embarrassing first-round Champions League elimination, leading to his dismissal late in the campaign. Veteran coach Carles Rexach took over, initially as an interim, and managed to secure the final Champions League spot on the season's last day. Despite improved La Liga performance and a strong Champions League semi-final run, Rexach was not considered a long-term option, and Louis van Gaal returned for his second managerial stint that summer. His return, despite another respectable Champions League showing, preceded one of the club's poorest La Liga campaigns, with the team plummeting to 15th by February 2003. This prompted van Gaal's resignation, with Radomir Antić stepping in for the remainder of the season, though he could only manage a sixth-place finish. Antić's short-term contract was not extended at season's end, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his role becoming untenable after a disastrous season compounded the club's overall decline since his presidency began three years earlier.
